courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History for Today
courses.description: This course teaches the art and science of historical research. It enhances Innovation and Design (I&D) by encouraging students to think out of the box, with critical thinking from multiple angles, with high ethical standard, and be innovative and creative. It enhances Global Citizenship and Social Enterprisingness (GC&SE) by fostering students’ ability and readiness to embark on creative and new ventures of social value in a global context, in line with global and ethical values. The topics will be adjusted every year based on a flexible and student-oriented approach. Details of the curriculum are available in the course website of the Department of History.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will:

a) have acquired satisfactory understanding of the art and science of historical research.

b) have enhanced capability of Innovation and Design (I&D) by developing critical thinking.

c) have enhanced capability of Global Citizenship and Social Enterprisingness (GC&SE) by fostering ability and readiness to embark on creative and new ventures of social value in a global context, in line with global and ethical values.

d) have enhanced writing, reading and communication skills.

courses.title: Tradition and Transformation in Chinese History
courses.description: This course examines the macro history of China by way of studying changes of traditional ideology, historical geography, state institutions and political reforms.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEA2223 or 2230

By the end of the course, students will:

(1) Learn how to examine the macro history of China;

(2) 透視中國傳統思想、歷史地理、經濟演變和政治。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Tradition and Transformation in Western History
courses.description: This course examines the main historical events in Western Civilization from Mesopotamia to the twentieth century. Major historical themes of the West and their significance are introduced in order to attain a macro-historical understanding of Western Civilization.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken GENA2112 or UGEC1221
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will:

1. Be able to have a better understanding of the tradition and transformation of the western history and culture;
2. Be able to critically think about related issues of the west;
3. Be able to gain a basic understanding of the history and development of the world as a whole.

3. 基本了解整體世界歷史之發展。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Introduction to Public History: Theory and Practice
courses.description: The field of public history has been expanding so rapidly since its inception in the 1970s that even public historians find it difficult to agree on a precise definition for public history. This course adopts a broad definition, which seeks to understand public history as a discipline in which historians practice history with a public audience in mind, and as a medium through which the general public acquire a sense of the past. Major topics examined in this course include museums, heritage, films, public monuments and tourism, etc. Local and global examples are used.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. understand the roles history and historians play in various public settings in Hong Kong and in other countries

2. analyze the popular use of history in everyday life

3. gain awareness of the ethical concerns within the discipline of public history

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History for Tomorrow: Technology and the Humanities
courses.description: Computer games, apps and AI are everywhere in the lives of CUHK students. These technologies are useful in our everyday interactions, but they can also help us be better historians and humanists. In this introductory course, you will learn about the exciting field of Digital Humanities (especially Digital History), which applies all manner of technologies to scholarly questions. The course will introduce the resources available at CUHK for digital history and humanities (DS Lab, VR Studio, 3-Printing space, etc.). It will also involve the study of some exciting applications of tools, like VR, text analysis, 3-D modeling and printing, historical mapping, etc. At the end of the course, students will have a solid foundation for further studies in digital history and digital humanities more broadly.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Consider the relationship between technology and humanities studies (especially history)

2. Learn about the resources at CUHK for digital scholarship (including UL DS Lab, VR Studio, etc.)

3. Acquire practical skills in digital humanities (especially digital history) that will be useful for more advanced courses

4. Apply these practical skills to address specific scholarly questions in a variety of historical periods and locations

5. Collaborate with other students to create a final project

3. 掌握實用的數位人文學（特別是數位史學）技能，讓同學能夠在更高階段的科目中應用

4. 利用這些的實用技能處理不同歷史時期與地方的學術問題

5. 與同學合作完成研究計劃

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Introduction to World History: Antiquity
courses.description: The ancient Mediterranean world (c. 800 BCE-250 CE) is often seen as the fountainhead of “Western” culture, but what was it really like? This course aims to help students understand the core contributions (philosophical, political, literary, etc.) of the ancient Mediterranean world to later periods of “Western” history, and its relationship to the rest of the world (Han China, India, ancient Near East, etc.). To do so, we will focus on a series of “moments” (and the related sources), which either had a particular influence on later periods or display the interconnectedness of the ancient world. It will also include a visit to the University Library to examine reproductions of ancient Western material culture.
courses.learning_outcomes:

courses.description: This course provides a broad survey of world history in the Middle Ages, with a particular focus on Europe and the Middle East. It shows how the medieval West inherited and built on the achievements of the ancient Greeks and Romans, becoming part of a wide, cosmopolitan world with well-established connections to Africa and Asia. Each week's lecture will explore a specific period and theme, after which students will have the chance to read samples of academic scholarship by experts on each topic and discuss related issues in conversation with classmates in tutorial sessions. By the end of the course, students will have a firm grasp of the basics of the medieval world and understand how the Western Middle Ages fit into the broader history of Eurasia in this period.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To teach students the fundamentals of medieval world history: key dates, events, places, states, beliefs, innovations, etc.

2. To familiarise students with the most important debates and methodological approaches in medieval world history.

3. To help students develop the fundamental skillset and sensibility of a historian: how to understand primary sources, how to think critically about historical narratives, and how to effectively communicate their analysis to others.

courses.description: This course will focus on Western and World History from 1500 until the present, with a focus on the global transformations that brought previously isolated parts of the world into contact with each other. It will begin with the emergence of Europe on the world stage during the sixteenth century with its Age of Exploration and its expansion into the Americas. It will then proceed through the main dynamics of world history both within The West and in its interactions with the peoples of the Americas, the Middle East, and Africa-through subsequent waves of colonization, the rise of industrialization, the World Wars, the Cold War, and the decolonization that took place during the 1950s and 1960s, through to the end of the Cold War and the emergence of the modern world order.
courses.learning_outcomes:

3. To teach students how to work with primary sources.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: China Today
courses.description: This course examines prominent issues in contemporary China and its development in the world system from a historical perspective.
courses.learning_outcomes:
修畢本科後，學生當能：
1. 明白廿世紀七十年代至廿一世紀初之間中國大陸在改革和現代化過程中所經歷的重大變化。

2. 認識有關中國當代史的各種概念、觀點和角度、研究現況、方法、史料、及重要著述。

3. 透過上課、導修、閱讀及功課，掌握中國當代史的發展脈絡，及對重要問題作出批判分析。

4. 通過口頭和文字報告表述以上有關史識。

5. 在作業中展示對中國當代史的綜合、說明和解釋能力以及研究潛力。
courses.course_syllabus:
講授重點及目標
本科重點在探討廿世紀七十年代至廿一世紀初之間中國大陸在改革和現代化過程中所經歷的重大變化，涉及黨國權力結構、國家與社會、中央與地方的關係、政治文化、經濟發展以及中國在世界體系中的地位等問題，兼及當代台灣社會的轉型及其啟示。除發展脈絡的闡述及重要問題的分析外，本科尚注重各種概念、觀點和角度及重要著述的評介。學生可透過上課、導修、閱讀及功課，掌握以上課程內容，並作出分析研判。
講授專題及閱讀材料
1 概述：有關當代中國的解釋模式、微觀分析與批判反思

2 “毛澤東時代”的影響與變化之源

3 放映錄像帶及堂上討論：文革後遺症

4 合法性基礎的轉換與“鄧小平時代”的歷史意義

5 國家與社會關係的悖論

6 “改革開放”的難題與“六四天安門事件”的根源

7 放映錄像帶及堂上討論：改革反思

8 “後鄧小平時代”的中央與地方

9 第三、四代領導層與國內外衝擊

10 來自海峽對岸的挑戰

11 台灣經驗與黨國模式的蛻變

12 放映錄像帶及堂上討論：台灣啟示

13 體制轉型與兩岸政治社會變化

14 總結：民主化及其他 ── “新權威主義”、“社會主義民主” 、 “後共產主義、“資本主義世界體系” 或第三條道路?

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Qin-Han China
courses.description: This course aims to study the major development of the first unitary empires in China, the Qin and the Han. Focus will be put on the changes of political, social and institutional patterns. Topics include significant political events, institutions of the central and the regional governments, social organization as well as the development of commerce and handicraft industries.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Understand the discipline concepts of political history through the study of the history of Qin and Han empires.

- Develop critical thinking by examining some of the conventional wisdoms in the study of Chinese history.

- Grasp presentation skills through discussion in tutorials.

- Learn to use the solid knowledge of standard histories.

- 瞭解秦漢帝國的政治發展。

- 透過考察中國歷史的問題以培養批判思維。

- 透過導修課學習書面及口頭報告的技巧。

- 學習使用正史的知識。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Transformations in Tang-Song China
courses.description: This course intends to examine the political, diplomatic, social, economic and cultural transformations from Tang to Song China, with emphasis on the political centralization by autocratic monarchy, the structural changes of society and economy as well as the evolving socio-cultural life. It will enable students to master the basic concepts, knowledge and empirical methods for the study of the theory of the T’ang-Song transformation in multiple perspectives through PowerPoint lectures, interactive tutorials, primary text readings and documentary film appreciation.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to historical sources for the Sui, T’ang and Song dynasties

It introduces various kinds of sources for the three dynasties including official histories, biographies, chronologies, institutional histories, encyclopaedia, unofficial histories, fictions, unearthed relics and documents, etc.

2. Review of recent studies on the periodization based on the T’ang-Song transformation

It reviews the different periodization based on the transformation by the Kyoto school and Tokyo school in Japan and other scholars in China, Taiwan and U.S.

3. The centralized administration system under the legal codes (ritsuryo) in the T’ang dynasty and the development from equal-field system to the manorial system

It demonstrates the evolution of penal codex, administrative codex, amendments to penal codex and enforcement regulations, the T’ang administration system under the legal code especially the ideal equal-field system and its reality, and the development of the manorial system in the late T’ang and Song dynasties.

4. From grain-labour-kind tax system to double tax system

It examines the grain-labour-kind tax system and its defects, the advantages of the double tax system in the T’ang dynasty, and the remarkable changes in the latter system from the late T’ang to the Song dynasty, and the historical significance of the transformation from the former system to the latter.

5. Collapse of the bureaucratic and military systems under the legal codes (ritsuryo), and formation and institutionalization of various commissioners (I)

It explains the operation, features and breakdown of the bureaucratic system and the garrison militia system, and the rise of various commissioners in the T’ang dynasty.

6. Collapse of the bureaucratic and military systems under the legal codes (ritsuryo) and formation and institutionalization of various commissioners (II)

It investigates the power expansion and institutionalization of the state fiscal commissioners, military affairs commissioners and Hanlin academicians from the late T’ang to the Song dynasty, and the development of the threefold parallel official system which consisted of vane ranks (guan), vane titles (zhi) and temporary ordinances (chaiqian) to control the recalcitrant military commissioners in the Song dynasty.

7. The policy of power centralization with emphasis on Confucianism and the idea of "civil first, martial second"

It analyses the relationships between the military commissionaries and the change of regimes in the late T’ang and Five Dynasties, and the policy of power centralization with emphasis on Confucianism and the idea of "civil first, martial second".

8. From power struggles to conflicts between different political factions: Evolution of court factionalism in the T’ang-Song period

It examines the power struggles headed by the imperial families before the reign of Emperor Shunzhong in the T’ang dynasty and the formation and development of political factionalism from the reign to the Song dynasty.

9. Class system and the decline of lowly people and growth of free people

It analyses the class system which consisted of the emperor, aristocracy, officials, common people and lowly people in the T’ang dynasty. It also traces the process of the breakdown of lowly people system and the rise of free people to demonstrate the collapse of class system in the T’ang Song period.

10. Decline of aristocracy and rise of literati

It shows the rise and fall of aristocracy in the T’ang dynasty and the growth and uniqueness of literati in the Song dynasty.

11. Southward shift of the national economic center

It analyses the gradual shift of the national economic center from North China to South China especially the regions of the middle and lower reaches of Yangtze River in the period from the An Lu-shan rebellion to the Song dynasty and its crucial factors.

12. Rise of commodity-monetary economy and urban revolution

It demonstrates the transformation of natural economy into commodity-monetary economy in the T’ang dynasty by which the walled-ward system broke down and guilds flourished. It also shows that the commercial and social functions of cities became more active which made urban life focused on the lower classes.

13. Rise of vernacular literatures: From the T’ang popular lecture to the Song story telling

It demonstrates the forms and contents of the popular lectures and the dance with music in the T’ang dynasty, and the evolution of the popular lecture into the story telling in the Song dynasty.

14. The changing role of the Sui, T’ang and Song Empires in the international order of East Asia

It explores the diplomatic relations of the Sui, T’ang and Song dynasties with the neighbouring countries under the canonized system and tributary state system, and particularly the changing role of the three Empires in the international order of East Asia.

1. 唐宋史料入門

本課簡介唐宋時代的各類原始史料，包括紀傳體正史、傳記、編年、政典、會要、類書、雜史、小說、出土古物及文獻等。

2. 「唐宋變革」的歷史分期研究回顧

本課回顧日本的京都學派、東京學派及中國、臺灣、美國等地的學者對唐宋變革期的時代分期理論。

3. 唐朝律令體制及均田制轉向莊園制之發展

本課說明律、令、格、式制度的形成發展、唐朝律令體制尤其均田制的理想與運作實況，以及唐朝後期至宋朝莊園制的演變發展。

4. 從租庸調制到兩稅制之演變

本課考察唐朝的租庸調制及其弊病、兩稅制的優點和其制在唐宋之間的內容變化，以及兩種稅制更替的歷史意義。

5. 律令官僚兵制崩壞與唐宋使職之興起及中樞機構化(1)

本課探討唐朝律令體制下的官僚制和府兵制的運作、特徵及崩潰情況，以及各種使職之興起。

6. 律令官僚兵制崩壞與唐宋使職之興起及中樞機構化(2)

本課探討晚唐至宋朝三司使、樞密院、翰林學士的職權擴展和制度化趨勢，又說明宋朝針對晚唐五代方鎮擅權而產生的官、職、差遣分合發展。

7. 唐末五代政局之反動－宋朝的強幹弱枝及崇儒右文政策

本課分析晚唐五代方鎮跟中央政權的統治更替之關係，以及宋朝的強幹弱枝、右文抑武政策。

8. 黨爭型態之轉變－從權力鬥爭到政見之爭

本課考察唐德宗朝以前以皇室貴族為首的統治集團內部派系權力鬥爭，以及順宗朝至五代、宋朝政見黨爭的形成與發展。

9. 身分制社會與賤民、良民佃戶之消長

本課剖析由皇帝、貴族、官僚、良民、賤民組成的唐代身分制社會，又考察賤民制破壞與自由民階層誕生的過程，以說明身分制社會崩壞的一個重要方面。

10. 門閥衰落與士大夫之興起

本課說明唐朝門閥士族的形成、發展及沒落，以及宋朝士大夫的興起及其獨特性格。

11. 國家經濟重心之南移

本課分析唐安史之亂以後至宋朝期間國家經濟重心從北方逐漸南移至長江中下游地區的過程，並說明導致南移的重要因素。

12. 商品貨幣經濟之興盛與城市規制之變革

本課說明唐朝的自然經濟向商品貨幣經濟轉型，坊市制度崩壞，行會盛行，城市的商業、社會功能逐漸提升，城市生活轉以社會下層為中心。

13. 通俗文學之誕生－從唐代俗講到宋元說話

本課探討唐代俗講和大麯的體例及內容，並說明俗講在後來轉變成為宋代的說話。

14. 東亞國際秩序與帝國地位之轉變

本課考察隋、唐、宋三朝透過冊封與朝貢制度與鄰近外族國家建立之關係，尤其三朝在東亞國際秩序中所扮演的角色和地位之轉變。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Ming China
courses.description: This course analytically presents the major national, political, social and cultural events during the period 1350-1683, from the outbreak of the late Yuan rebellion to the end of the nominal Ming regime in Taiwan. The establishment of important institutions and implementation of important policies, accounts of political incidents of far-reaching consequences, and literati performance in government and local society will be given special attention.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, students should be able to achieve the following objectives:

1. Gain a solid training in the craftsmanship of academic presentation and historiographical writing;
2. Identify, understand, and critically analyze major episodes and events in the history of the Ming dynasty;
3. Demonstrate profound understanding and critical analysis of various types of Ming historical archives.

學生完成課程後，將能：
1. 在作學術報告及寫作歷史學論文方面得到扎實的訓練；

2. 辨別、理解、及分析明朝歷史上的主要時段及重大事件；

3. 充分理解及深入分析各種明朝史料。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Taiwan
courses.description: The aim of the course is to provide an opportunity for students to understand the history of Taiwan from prehistory to modern period. The colonization polices of Dutch and Japanese will be discussed in the course, so as the political and social changes after the coming of Kuomintang.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course provides a general background for students to:

a. broaden the knowledge of modern china;
b. broaden the cross-strait political knowledge;
c. comprehend the general history of Taiwan.

a. 加深對近代中國的認識。

b. 加深兩岸政局的理解。

c. 使學生對台灣史有一般的認識。

1 前言

10 美麗島事件及民進黨的興起

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Song, Liao, Jin, and Yuan
courses.description: This course aims to enhance students' understanding of the transition period from the tenth century to the fourteenth century in the Imperial China. Additionally, it provides students a comprehensive overview of key research questions in the historical study of Song, Liao, Jin and Yuan periods.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course helps students to:

1) Perceive Song, Liao, Jin and Yuan history from a multi-national perspective.

2) Understand the fundamental concepts of Song political history.

3) Gain a basic knowledge of the characters of Liao, Jin and Yuan governance in China as Conquest Dynasties

4) The social and intellectual changes in the Song-Yuan transition

(一) 多強格局中的宋遼金元史

(二) 兩宋的基本「國是」與政治文化

(三) 遼、金、元作為征服王朝的基本特征與其中原政策

(四) 宋元之際的思想和社會轉變
courses.course_syllabus:
1) An Introduction to some basic research approaches concerning Song, Liao, Jin, and Yuan history

2) Exploring Song, Liao, and Xixia history from a multi-national perspective.

3) The foundation of the Northern Song Empire and its basic regulatory system

4) Strategic culture, military operations, and pacifism: military history from the Liao perspective

5) The great turn of political culture during the Major Reform

6) Song Huizong: an ambitious emperor

7) Cities and the urban culture of the Song China

8) Poltical characters of the Jin Dynasty and the North China in the twelfth century

9) Internal and diplomatic moves of the Southern Song Dynasty

10) The dual nature of the Mongol Empire as a Conquest Dynasty

11) Ethnical issues under the Mongol ruleship

12) Dowry: a fundamental change in the transition period from Song to Yuan

13) Imagined "Song Learning" and "neo-Confucianism"

14) Conclusive remark: the turning point of Chinese history--Tang-Song transition or Song-Yuan-Ming transition?

第一講: 宋遼金元史的基本研究面向與進路

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Walking through Chinese History
courses.description: This is a course on general and macro history of China. Non-local students and exchange students are particularly welcome. This course will explore episodes, events, thoughts and people that determined or changed the course of Chinese history in the past two millennia. Apart from classroom lectures, fieldtrips and other cultural activities in Hong Kong, Macau, or Mainland China might be organized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for HIstory Majors. Not for student who have taken HIST1001.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are able to
1. Understand general Chinese History.
2. Examine the continuity between 'traditional' and 'modern' China.
3. Appreciate Chinese cultural and aesthetics

修習完此科後，學生能夠
1. 對中國歷史有一定程度的理解。
2. 比較古代及現代中國的傳承。
3. 欣賞中國的文化及美學。

courses.description: This course will give a brief introduction to the new discovery of ancient China in the light of archaeological theories and materials. Focus will be put on the regional interactions from prehistory to the pre-Qin periods. It is hoped that through this course students can gain a basic knowledge of the ancient Chinese history from an archaeological perspective. This course would be invaluable for anyone interested in Chinese antiquities and Chinese views on the formation of their own civilization.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Early Medieval China (200s - 590s CE)
courses.description: This course examines the development of Chinese history in the early medieval period (200s - 590s CE) from various aspects, including politics, military, ethnicity, religious beliefs, and intellectual trends, to analyze its significance as a transition period between two models of empire in Chinese history. It further adopts a comparative perspective to study the significance of the period in a world historical context. In addition, it also provides a survey of the state-of-arts in the field as a base for advanced research.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the history of early medieval China in various aspects, including politics, economy, military, and culture, etc.

2. Learn the different definitions of medievality of China in Sinological context.

3. Analyze the dynamics of social development in early medieval China.

4. Develop a comparative perspective of reading the history of early medieval China in a world historical context.

5. Acquire critical and analytical skills of reading historical sources.

1. 從政治、經濟、軍事和文化等多元角度認識魏晉南北朝的歷史發展

3. 學習分析該時期社會發展的動力

4. 培養以比較史和世界歷史的視野以了解魏晉南北朝時期的中國歷史

5. 訓練以批判性與分析性的技巧研讀歷史資料

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Reform and Modernization in Modern China
courses.description: This course examines China’s efforts for reform and modernization from late eighteenth to early twentieth century, with special reference to her convergence with world civilization.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to grasp dynamics, including twists and turns, of China’s century-long endeavors for reform and modernization, to understand where they succeeded and failed, and to reflect on the path taken in attempting to guage the appropriate road ahead.

學生應能了解百年來中國改革和現代化的成敗得失，以及反思中國現代化所走過的路，從而探討其可作當前中國現代化道路借鑑之處。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Revolution and Modernization in Twentieth-Century China
courses.description: This course examines the major political, social, economic, and cultural transformations in China from the 1920s to the late 1970s in the process of modern state-building, revolution, and modernization.
courses.learning_outcomes:
修畢本科後，學生當能：
1. 認識本世紀二十年代至七十年代末中國在建立現代國家、革命及現代化過程中所經歷的政治、經濟、社會及文化上的重大變化。

2. 掌握中國現代史的發展脈絡及對重要問題作出批判分析。

3. 了解有關中國現代史的各種概念、方法、史料、研究現況及重要著述。

4. 對民族主義與革命/現代化的課題作出研判。

5. 通過口頭和文字報告表述以上有關史識。

6. 在作業中展示對中國現代史的綜合、說明和解釋能力以及研究潛力。
courses.course_syllabus:
講授重點
本科環繞民族主義基調與革命/現代化雙重變奏的主題，討論廿世紀二十年代至七十年代中國在現代國家建構、革命及現代化過程中所經歷的重大變化。共分十三節，涉及民國時期的國家與社會關係、意識形態及文化的轉化、群眾運動、帝國主義侵略、內戰及政權轉移、中華人民共和國的建立、國家控制與社會改造、革命與現代化的矛盾，以及共產政權下中國社會的轉化等問題。除發展脈絡的闡述及重要問題的分析外，本科尚注重各種概念、方法、史料、研究現況及重要著述的評介。

講授專題
1. 緒言：民族主義、革命、現代化

2. 意識及文化的轉化：二十年代的中國

3. 十年建國：南京政府的建立及國民黨治下的社會經濟

4. 由城市至鄉村的革命：共產主義運動及江西與延安政權

5. 帝國主義衝擊與中國的戰時建國：日本侵華與中國抗戰

6. 權力角鬥與求變呼聲：國共內戰與“解放”前夕的社會

7. (放錄影帶及中期討論)

8. 國家控制與社會改造：共產政權的鞏固與社會主義過渡

9. 社會主義現代化：“大躍進”與“人民公社”

10. 危機出現與矛盾轉化：六十年代初的“兩條路線鬥爭”

11. 繼續革命的理想及其挫折：“文化大革命”

12. 毛澤東時代的總結：“四人幫”及“文革”後期的發展

13. 總結：民族主義基調與革命/現代化的雙重變奏

1. Be able to have a better understanding of the history and culture of ancient and medieval Europe;
2. Be able to critically think about related issues of ancient and medieval Europe;
3. Be able to gain a basic understanding of the ancient and medieval history and development of the world as a whole.

meetings.instructor: Professor James Deas David Jack MORTON

Professor James Deas David Jack MORTON
Professor James Deas David Jack MORTON

courses.description:
'War, comrades, is a great locomotive of history.'- Leon Trotsky (1922)

From the beginning of recorded history, states, rulers, and warlords have resorted to violent conflict in order to enforce their will on others. Nonetheless, while war has been a constant fact of life for human society, the methods of war have changed greatly over time. Wars have also driven immense changes in human society itself, often far beyond the original intentions of political and military leaders. This dynamic has had a powerful effect on the history of the Western world, shaping the development of Western states as we know them today.

This course will introduce students to the military history of the medieval West (c. AD 500-1500), focusing on Europe and surrounding regions of North Africa and Western Asia. Through weekly lectures, readings, and discussions, you will learn about key developments in military technology and tactics, as well as the decisive wars and battles in which they were put to the test.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Learn the basic facts and details of Western military history in the period c. AD 500-1500.
2. Understand how changes in medieval Western societies drove changes in military strategy and tactics, and vice-versa.
3. Develop the fundamental skillset and sensibility of a historian: how to understand academic arguments, think critically about historical narratives, and effectively communicate an analysis to others.

1. 同學將能夠掌握公元六世紀至十六世紀這一千年的歐洲軍事歷史的梗概。
2. 同學將能夠理解中世界歐洲社會與中世紀歐洲軍事策略戰術的互相影響。
3. 同學將掌握歷史學者的重要技巧與觸覺：如何理解史學界的相關論辯、如何分析和批判歷史敘述、如何有效地表達自己的觀點。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of the Byzantine Empire
courses.description: This course will introduce students to the Byzantine Empire, the modern name that we use to refer to the Eastern Roman Empire in the Middle Ages. Beginning with its origins in the late Roman period, it will cover the story of Byzantium up to its eventual destruction by the Ottoman Turks in 1453. In addition to covering narrative history, the course will also introduce students to several key themes and ideas from Byzantine culture and society such as law, religion, art, and literature. By studying both primary sources and modern scholarship, students will develop a firm understanding of Byzantine history and an appreciation of its place within the wider history of world empires.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Learn the key facts and details of the history of the Byzantine Empire in the period 527-1453.

2. Understand and be able to debate how and why historians have constructed narratives around the changing character of the Byzantine Empire.

3. Be able to compare and contrast the Byzantine Empire with other contemporary world empires such as China.

4. Develop skills in critically analysing and interpreting primary sources relating to the history of the Byzantine Empire.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of the United States
courses.description: This course discusses topics on American modern history and its interpretation. Contents may change, depending on the teacher's emphasis in the term concerned. The focus may shift from the situation prior to World War II to the post-war development.
courses.learning_outcomes: As befits the course’s thematic approach, its readings will give voice to many scholarly perspectives and will engage with a variety of primary sources that should be viewed as historical texts that open windows onto inquiries into the nature of class, gender, minority status, immigration, foreign relations, religion, technology, and culture. With our emphasis on critical thinking, essay writing, and primary source interpretation, not only will students be profoundly better informed as to the subject matter and demonstrably more expert on matters of historical investigation; you will also leave with an enhanced set of skills. After successfully completing the coursework, students will be better able to express ideas clearly in writing, to conduct scholarly research, to analyze information and to critique differing viewpoints, to compare and to contrast contrary cases of historical interpretation, to discern and to explain the links between historical events, and to assess the importance of historical documents or of cultural artifacts whether they comprise a political cartoon, book, painting, speech, song, or film.
courses.course_syllabus:
Our course will stand true to its name and explore modern American history rather than recount it. We will take a thematic rather than a progressive line of inquiry and essentially sacrifice the comforts of an orderly timeline for the challenges of a non-linear exploration. Chronology will not be eliminated as the lectures will roughly flow from the eighteenth through the twentieth centuries and the events and the movements we investigate will be placed in their temporal contexts, but we will be most interested in the links between different periods with regards to specific subjects. The weekly lecture topics include economics; territorial expansion; popular movements that originated outside government structures and the influence they later wielded within them; the betrayal, confrontations, and confinement of Native Americans; slavery and institutionalized bigotry; religion and popular culture; urban development; the causes of and responses to economic impoverishment; international relations; and crises of authority. For example, we will consider what the country’s “Founding Fathers” meant by their declaration of each individual’s right to the “pursuit of happiness,” and how that resulted in a clique of late nineteenth century “Robber Barons.”

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Singapore
courses.description: This course introduces and examines the historical development of Singapore since the British trade settlement in 1819, through the time of British colonialism, Japanese occupation, decolonization, self-government, merger with Malaysia, and finally nation-building after the independence in 1965 and up to the present. Apart from the political aspect of modern Singapore history, this course also examines the social, economic and cultural aspects of the historical development of modern Singapore over the past two centuries.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken HIST4308
courses.learning_outcomes:
The expected learning outcomes include:

1. The students can trace the historical development of Singapore and explain the factors that contributing to the rise of Singapore as a prominent British colony in the Far East region in the mid-nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries.

2. The students will be able to identify major characteristics of the historical development of modern Singapore since 1819 until nowadays. They can conduct more in-depth research on modern Singapore history from different perspectives, such as political, economic, social and cultural perspectives.

3. The students should be able to compare similarities and differences between the historical development of Singapore and other ex-British colonies especially in Asia, including Hong Kong.

本科所預期之學生學習成果，包括：
1. 學生能夠追溯新加坡的歷史發展，並解釋新加坡在19世紀中期至20世紀初期，成為英國在遠東地區相當重要的殖民地的原因。

2. 學生能夠指出新加坡自1819年至當今的歷史發展的主要特徴，而學生亦能夠從政治、經濟、社會及文化等不同角度，對現代新加坡歷史進行深入研究。

3. 學生能夠比較新加坡與其他亞洲地區中前英國殖民地，包括香港的歷史發展的異同。
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Singapore and Southeast Asia

- To introduce the course.

- To provide an overview of the historical origin and development of Singapore and the relationship between Singapore and Southeast Asia.

2. The Founding of Modern Singapore

- To examine the reasons for the British East India Company and Stamford Raffles being interested in building up a free trading port and factory in Singapore in the early nineteenth century.

- To evaluate critically the historical role of Stamford Raffles in the modern history of Singapore, and also how effective the British administration governed Singapore in the 1820s.

3. Singapore’s Colonial Economy

- To explain the factors contributing to the growing prosperity of the Singapore port-city as compared with its counterparts in Malacca and Penang since 1819.

- To discuss how far the opening of Hong Kong and other Chinese ports in the 1840s affected the economic prospects of Singapore.

4. The Chinese Society in Singapore

- To identify major characteristics of the Chinese society in Singapore. To differentiate two major groups of the Chinese residing in Singapore in the nineteenth century till the Japanese occupation in the 1940s, namely, the Straits Chinese and the newcomers or new immigrants from China.

- To compare and contrast these two groups of Chinese communities in Singapore from the political, social, economic and cultural perspectives.

5. The Fall of Singapore: Japanese Occupation

- To note the linkage between Singapore and Japan before the Japanese occupation in 1942.

- To discuss whether the fall of Singapore was inevitable, and the legacy of the Japanese occupation on the historical development of Singapore.

6. Decolonization: Self-Government, Merger and Independence

- To trace the development of the postwar Singapore with special reference to the process of decolonization, which was represented by the introduction of democratic elections, the setting up of the self-government, the pursuit of a merger between Singapore and Malaysia in 1963, and finally the separation between Singapore and Malaysia which led to the independence of Singapore on 9 August 1965.

- To account for the failure of the merger between Singapore and Malaysia between 1963-65.

7. Lee Kuan Yew and Nation-building of Singapore

- To review the political career of Lee Kuan Yew and his nation-building policies after the independence of Singapore in 1965.

- To evaluate the role and significance of Lee Kuan Yew and the People’s Action Party on the development of Singapore since they came to power in 1959 when the self-government was set up.

8. From Third World to First: Economic Miracle in Singapore

- To trace the economic development of Singapore after the Second World War.

- To explain how economic transformation works in Singapore to turn it from a Third World to First World country with special reference to the role of the state in developing the Singapore economy.

9. Pragmatic Social Policies for Political Hegemony

- To examine the concept of the “developmental state” in the context of the “Singapore model of social welfare” since the 1950s.

- To analyze how the ruling party in Singapore has been able to achieve and preserve its political hegemony through the institutionalization of a series of social policies, especially in terms of the Central Provident Fund and public housing programmes.

10. Education for Elitism and Meritocracy

- To investigate how elitism, meritocracy, patriotism, and Confucianism have been preached and consolidated through education in Singapore since 1965.

- To evaluate critically the social consequences of the education system in Singapore with reference to its impact on politico-socio-economic and ethnic disparities in the society

11. Singapore Cinema: From Run Run Shaw to Jack Neo

- To discuss the importance of the filmmaking industry and mass media in the shaping of popular culture in Singapore.

- To demonstrate how the social reality and problems of Singapore can be studied from Singapore-made movies, such as 12 Storeys, I Not Stupid, and Singapore Dreaming.

12. Singapore in a Globalized World

- To synthesize major changes and challenges facing Singapore from the nineteenth century onwards and in the context of globalization.

- To shed light on what can be learnt from the Singapore’s experience from different perspectives as covered in the course, and discuss whether the “Singapore model of development” can be copied or adopted in other places such as Hong Kong.

1. 新加坡與東南亞

- 簡介課程。

- 概括說明新加坡的歷史源起，及其與東南亞地區之關係。

2. 現代新加坡的奠基

- 探討英國東印度公司和萊佛士在19世紀初到新加坡建立自由商港的原因。

- 對英國統治者在19世紀20年代管治效能，以及萊佛士在現代新加坡歷史地位作出評價。

3. 新加坡在殖民地時代之經濟發展

- 研討新加坡得以自1819年，發展成為較馬六甲及檳城更為繁榮之海港城市的原因。

- 討論香港及其他中國港口自19世紀40年代開放對外通商後對新加坡經濟發展之影響。

4. 新加坡的華人社會

- 分析新加坡華人社會的特徵，並分辨兩個主要華人群體，包括海峽華人及新移民在19世紀至20世紀40年代日本佔領前的相異之處。

- 比較上述兩個主要新加坡華人群體在政治、社會、經濟及文化方面之異同。

5. 新加坡的淪陷：日本佔領

- 說明新加坡和日本兩地，在1942年日本佔領時期以前雙方的關係。

- 探討新加坡的淪陷是否能夠避免，以及日本佔領對新加坡歷史發展所產生的影響。

6. 去殖民地化：自治政府、合併與獨立

- 特別從去殖民地化的過程，當中涉及民主選舉、自治政府、新加坡與馬來西亞合併，以及新加坡脫離馬來西亞等歷史事件，追溯新加坡在戰後至1965年8月9日宣佈獨立的歷史發展。

- 解釋1963-65年間新加坡與馬來西亞合併失敗的原因。

7. 李光耀與新加坡建國

- 回顧李光耀的從政經歷，以及其在新加坡在1965年獨立以後所提出之建國政策。

- 為李光耀及人民行動黨自1959年新加坡成立自治政府執政，其對新加坡的發展之角色和影響作出評價。

8. 從第三到第一世界：新加坡的經濟奇蹟

- 追溯新加坡在第二次世界大戰後經濟發展過程。

- 解釋新加坡的經濟轉型，以及當地政府在發展經濟之角色，何以使新加坡由第三世界發展成為第一世界國家。

9. 務實的社會政策與政治霸權

- 闡釋「發展型國家」的概念，並應用該概念於探討自20世紀50年代以後，新加坡社會福利模式之性質。

- 分析執政黨如何透過一系列的社會政策及制度，當中以中央公積金制度與公共房屋政策為例，實現和維持其在新加坡的政治霸權。

10. 教育與精英及績效主義

- 探究精英主義、績效主義、愛國主義及儒家思想，何以透過1965年後新加坡的教育系統得以傳播和鞏固。

- 批判性地討論新加坡的教育制度之社會影響，並針對教育制度對當地社會中出現之政治、社會、經濟及種族不平等問題產生之影響作更深入討論。

11. 新加坡的電影：從邵逸夫到梁智強

- 討論電影業與大眾傳播媒介對建構新加坡普及文化之影響。

- 說明新加坡的電影可作為研習當地社會現實與問題之媒介，當中的電影包括：《十二樓》、《小孩不笨》、《美滿人生》等。

12. 在全球化下的新加坡

- 綜合新加坡自19世紀後，直至全球化所面對的主要變化和挑戰。

- 歸納新加坡的經驗，從本科所涉獵之不同角度，討論「新加坡發展模式」是否適用於香港和其他地方。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Japan
courses.description: This course explores the history and culture of Japan from the ancient time to the present. It covers the aspects of political and economic development, foreign relations, social thought, cultural feature, historical site and various typical literature of Japan in different periods. Through this course, students will gain a thorough understanding of the cultural evolution of Japan which was greatly influenced by the cultures of China, Europe and the U.S. successively, and the interactions among the developments of politics, society and literature in Japan. They will also be able to command the prospect of Japan and the Japanese culture in the 21st century. This course is interactive in nature. Lessons will be conducted in the forms of PowerPoint demonstration, multi-media learning (watching history film, documentary, TV program, drama, song and dance, music program and the Internet entertainment, etc), appreciation of photos of historical site and relic, selective reading of the traditional and pop literature, class discussion, interactive tutorial and e-learning modules.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Korea
courses.description: This course introduces and examines the historical development of Korea over the past 2,000 years up to the present. It covers the imperial era comprising the periods of Three Kingdoms, Koryo Dynasty, and Chosen Dynasty, which ended in 1910 when Japan annexed Korea, the period of Japanese colonialism, independence movement and Korean War, and subsequently the separation between South and North Koreas, each of which has experienced extremely divergent pathways of development since the 1950s. The course also analyzes and discusses major factors that affecting the transformation of Korea over different stages of historical development.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. The students can trace and analyze the historical development of Korea and explain the factors that affecting its historical development.

2. The students will be able to identify major characteristics of the historical development of Korea during ancient, medieval, modern and contemporary periods.

3. The students should be able to conduct more in-depth research on Korean history, and also explore the relationship between Korea and other major powers in Asia, including China, Japan, the US and Russia (formerly the Soviet Union) since the twentieth century.

1. 學生能夠敘述及分析韓國的歷史發展過程，並解釋影響韓國歷史發展的重要因素。

2. 學生能夠辨別韓國在古代、中古時代、現代及當代歷史發展的特點。

3. 學生能夠對韓國歷史進行更深入的研究，並了解自二十世紀以來韓國與主要影響亞洲地區發展的國家，包括中國、日本、美國，以及俄羅斯 (前蘇聯) 的關係。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Hong Kong History in the Field
courses.description: This course will introduce the history of Hong Kong by focusing on its “fields”. It will examine how various field sites (such as temples, museums, historical trails, and renovated historical buildings) could be used to understand the history of different places, events, and people in Hong Kong from the ancient period to the present. After a brief introduction to the historical development of Hong Kong, the course will discuss aspects of rural Hong Kong history before moving on urban Hong Kong. The last section of the course will explain the diversity of Hong Kong’s communities, cultures, and religions. To help students understand Hong Kong, the course will organize several day trips to Hong Kong Island, Kowloon Peninsula, and the New Territories.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for HIstory Majors. Not for student who have taken HIST2500/ HIST2701.

- Learn Hong Kong history from field visits

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Leadership Lessons from History
courses.description: History is full of examples of leaders faced with challenges that mirror the modern world. In this course, we will consider the lessons for leadership offered by a variety of historical figures, with a focus on ancient Greece and Rome. By balancing historical specificity with universal applicability, this course will teach students about both the past and the present. This course will also give an opportunity for working on communication skills. There is no final paper. Instead, students will complete a multimedia project (either Tableau project or scholarly video documentary, both with accompanying text commentaries).

2. Understand ethnical issues inherent in leadership roles through historical examples.
3. Improve communication skills applicable to leadership roles, including using digital technologies.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Local History and Public History
courses.description: This course examines the history of Hong Kong from a public history perspective. Chronologically and thematically organized, its lectures examines the places, peoples, and cultures of Hong Kong from the ancient period up to the present in the major fields of public history. These fields include archaeology, oral history, popular culture, public museums, archives, cultural heritage, and digital history. This course will make extensive use of historical images, videos, oral records, antiquities, monuments, and scholarly writings on local history and public history.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken HIST2501
courses.learning_outcomes:
• To identify the major themes and topics pertaining to the local history and public history of Hong Kong

• To appreciate how, in the fields of local history and public history, Hong Kong is related to Mainland China and other parts of the world

• To understand how history is written based on our contemporary understanding of and interest in the past

• To develop among the students skills to conduct research and produce writings on local history as a public historian

• 掌握與香港本地史學和公眾史學相關之主要課題

• 明白在本地史學與公眾史學中，香港如何與中國內地及世界其他地方互相連繫

• 了解歷史書寫是如何建基於當代對於過去的理解與興趣

• 培養學生從事本地史學與公眾史學研究所需之技巧

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Daily Life in Han China
courses.description: This course examines the everyday life of various classes in Han China (BCE 206 - 220 CE), with emphasis on life in the cities, occult powers, marriage customs, funeral rites, etc.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Understand the basic development of Han society through the study of the important aspects of Chinese life during the period of Han Dynasty.

- Develop critical thinking by examining some of the conventional wisdoms in the study of Chinese history.

- Grasp presentation skills through discussion in tutorials.

- Learn to use the solid knowledge of standard histories and unearthed documents, such as bamboo slips and wooden tablets.

- 透過探討漢代人們的重要生活狀況以瞭解漢代社會的基本發展。

- 透過考察中國歷史的問題以培養批判思維。

- 透過導修課學習書面及口頭報告的技巧。

- 學習使用正史和相關出土文書的知識。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Political Disintegration and Social Integration: China from 220-581 CE
courses.description: This course examines the political, social and cultural changes of China during the long period of disunion from 220 to 581 CE, with the emphasis on the disintegration and integration of the states and society. The topics will cover the ethnic assimilation, cultural and political impacts on the aristocratic families.
courses.learning_outcomes:

- Develop critical thinking by examining some of the conventional wisdoms in the study of Chinese history.

- Grasp presentation skills through discussion in tutorials.

- Learn to use the solid knowledge of standard histories.

- 瞭解魏晉南北朝時期（公元220至581年）的政治與社會發展。

- 透過考察中國歷史的問題以培養批判思維。

- 透過導修課學習書面及口頭報告的技巧。

- 學習使用正史的知識。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Social and Cultural History of Song China
courses.description: The Song dynasty has been acclaimed by its culture in Chinese history. Song culture originated from the aristocratic and military society of the Tang and Five Dynasties (~7th-10th centuries) and paved the way for the proliferation of educated shi-elites and lineage system in the successive Yuan and Ming dynasties (~13th-17th centuries). Given the principal position of Song dynasty in Chinese history, it is of particular importance to explore Song culture and society, as well as their influence and interaction with the foreign dynasties in northern China. Chinese culture in the future does not necessarily follows the Song pattern. Nonetheless, Song culture and society still deserves the keen attention of modern Chinese.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Chinese Maritime Connections in Asia, 1500-1800
courses.description: This course aims to show how the passages of Chinese people, ships, commodities, and ideas connected different maritime regions in East and Southeast Asia and other parts of the world in the early modern era (c. 1500-1800). It takes into account the state policies of China, other Asian “indigenous” polities, and European “imperialists,” and the activities of different Chinese groups such as merchants, sailors, pirates, and settlers in China, Japan, and Southeast Asia. Assisted by a variety of textual, cartographic, and pictorial sources, the course explores the roles of various forms of Chinese circulations such as tribute trade, smuggling, and migration in forming an Asian macro-region with its own intrinsic political, social, economic, and cultural orders. Students will have much chance to read historical materials and secondary literature in both English and Chinese.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Having taken this course, students should be able to:

• Understand the various ways in which the circulations of Chinese people, ships, commodities, and ideas linked different regions of maritime Asia and other parts of the world from 1500 to 1800;
• Weave Chinese maritime history into East Asian history, Southeast Asian history, and the history of European empires, and understand maritime history as an analytical approach to world history, regional history, and local history
• Appreciate the historical roots of contemporary links across maritime Asia such as migration, trading networks, and cultural flows; and
• Engage in academic discussions and analyze primary sources on specific historical issues related to the Chinese presence in maritime Asia during the lectures and tutorial lessons and in a variety of written assignments.

完成本課程後，學生應能夠：

• 理解1500年至1800年間華人及其船隻、商品和思想的流動如何將亞洲不同的海洋地區與世界其他地方聯繫起來；
• 將中國海洋史融入東亞歷史、東南亞歷史和歐洲帝國史，並理解海洋史作爲研究世界史、區域史和地方史的研究方法；
• 從移民、貿易網絡和文化流動等議題理解當代亞洲海洋地區各地聯繫的歷史根源；
• 在講課、導修課以及不同作業中參與學術討論並分析中國與海洋亞洲相關的歷史問題。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Intellectual Landscape of the Middle Periods of China
courses.description: Since the second half of the eighth century, China underwent a great transformation in terms of intellectual landscape. From the perspective of the dynasties of the Central Plain, the transition period from the late Tang to early Ming serves as a watershed in Chinese intellectual history. Through the investigation and analysis of some crucial cultural and intellectual norms during this period, this course aims to lead students into the intellectual landscape of the Middle Periods of China. Master Lu's Annals of Spring and Autumn mentions how antiquity and contemporiness are connected to each other in essence. This course attempts to provide a platform for students to comprehend the thoughts of past people. Thereby they can understand the value and meaning of studying intellectual history.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) To understand the role played by intellectual history in histroical studies
2) To examine some basic concepts and ideas in Chinese intellecutual history through historical and philosophical lens
3) To explore the social context of the intellectual landscape of the Middle Periods of China (8th to 14th centuries)
4) To inquiry into the origins of some pre-modern Chinese thoughts

courses.title: Social and Economic History of Modern China
courses.description: This course examines traditional Chinese society and its modern transformation. It discusses the socio-economic institutions that stimulate or restrict China’s modernisation. Emphasis will be placed on (1) basic socio-economic structures; (2) matters of social stratification and mobilization; (3) markets and regional systems, process of urbanization and the movement of commodities; and (4) interrelationship of state economy and local society. Lectures will be supplemented by participant observations in the field and subsequent discussion sessions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- As part of the Department’s public and comparative history curriculum, this course provides students with an alternative interpretation on the development of China in the Modern period.

- Students will understand the foundation, operation, organization and changes of Chinese local societies and their interaction with the State from a cross-disciplinary perspective.

- Students are expected to construct their own analysis framework which, hopefully, could be applied in their daily activities.

- 作為本系的公眾及比較歷史的課程，本課提供學生對近代中國的發展的一個新的認識

- 從跨學科的視角，幫助學生理解中國地方社會的基本建構、運作、組織和變遷，以及地方社會和國家的互動關係

- 幫助學生建立自身的分析框架，並且可以運用到日常活動之中

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: 19th Century European History
courses.description: The course surveys Europe's "Long Century" from the outbreak of the French Revolution to the run-up to the First World War. The 19th Century saw the rise of nationalism, the advent of wide-scale industrialization, the establishment of socio-economic classes, and the rise of competing governing philosophies, along with a myriad of other factors that brought the western world into its modernity. During this "Long Century" Europe acquired unparalleled wealth, power, and influence. In spite of this expansion many Europeans endured a daily slog for their existence; the struggles of the proletariat will receive the same sort of consideration as the decaying aristocracies and the ascending middle-classes. Students will experience this vibrant period by use of a variety of investigative tools—primary sources (both political and cultural) and the analysis offered by a wide selection of historians.
courses.learning_outcomes: With our emphasis on critical thinking, essay writing, and primary source interpretation, not only will students be profoundly better informed as to the subject matter and demonstrably more expert on matters of historical investigation; you will also leave with an enhanced set of skills. After successfully completing the coursework, students will be better able to express ideas clearly in writing, to conduct scholarly research, to analyze information and to critique differing viewpoints, to compare and to contrast contrary cases of historical interpretation, to discern and to explain the links between historical events, and to assess the importance of historical documents or of cultural artifacts whether they comprise a political cartoon, book, painting, speech, song, or film.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Modern Europe
courses.description: The course surveys Europe's "Long" (19th) and "Short" (20th) Centuries, i.e. from the outbreak of the French Revolution (1789) to the fall of the Berlin Wall (1989). It will detail the major political, economic, philosophical, and social events of this period and will examine them as a series of interwoven threads rather than as separate events. This period gave full vent to the forces of industrialization, capitalism, nationalism, imperialism, and communism while it provided the conditions for artistic innovation, philosophical competition, and scientific advancement. During these 200 years, as a continent Europe achieved its height in military, cultural, and commercial power; it then engaged in a period of violent self-destruction; finally, after profound ideological and territorial division, it reinvented itself. How the scope and volatility of the changes brought about during this time manifested themselves in the lives of ordinary men, women, and children, as well as in the affairs among nations, will receive due attention. Readings for the course will hear from many scholarly voices and will engage with a variety of primary sources that should be viewed as historical texts that open windows onto inquiries into the nature of class, gender, minority status, religion, technology, and culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken HIST4306
courses.learning_outcomes: With our emphasis on critical thinking, essay writing, and primary source interpretation, not only will students be profoundly better informed as to the subject matter and demonstrably more expert on matters of historical investigation; you will also leave with an enhanced set of skills. After successfully completing the coursework, students will be better able to express ideas clearly in writing, to conduct scholarly research, to analyze information and to critique differing viewpoints, to compare and to contrast contrary cases of historical interpretation, to discern and to explain the links between historical events, and to assess the importance of historical documents or of cultural artifacts whether they comprise a political cartoon, book, painting, speech, song, or film.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Modern Britain
courses.description: This course examines British history from Victorian period to the twentieth century. It will detail the major political, economic, philosophical, artistic, scientific, and social events of this period and will examine them as a series of interwoven threads rather than as separate events. Consider that during the span of our investigation this small island state and its collection of nationalities came to exert control and influence over a quarter of the world's land mass and for much of the time operated as unchallenged mistress of the seas. The course proceeds as an empirical examination of the progress of multiple facets of British history, but all along our inspection we will confront the question as to what it meant (means) to be British.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are able to have a full grip of modern British history after this course. They will be able to express ideas clearly and to analyze information and to critique differing viewpoints by the end of this course. With the knowledge of modern British history and the development of the British Empire, students are able to understand the globalization in the beginning of the century, which enhances their values of Global Citizenship in the modern time.

It therefore deserves a place in any historical curriculum.It shows both the power of ideas to shape events and the ability of events to transcend the ideas that originally inspired them. courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Colonial and Revolutionary America
courses.description: The course will begin with a discussion of the arrival of Europeans in North America and the development of English colonies in North America and, to a lesser extent, the West Indies. It will continue with the development of colonial society with an emphasis on the role of race relations; the different dynamics in each colony; and the importance of slavery. The second part of the course will go over the deterioration of relations between England and its American colonies, the importance of Republicanism in shaping colonists' self-understanding, before shifting to the Declaration of Independence and the course of the war with England, before moving on to the formulation of the U.S. Constitution and the debates between the Federalists and the Anti-Federalists.

5) The role of racial relations in American society

In addition, the course would focus on the following skills

1) working with primary texts from the era

2) evaluating competing interpretations

Starting from the general geography and how the region was named and recognized by outsiders through the history, the lectures illustrates the development of commerce, Chinese migration, colonial powers, plantation landscape and economy, wars and nationalism. Students will study ethnic groups, all the major religions, thriving powers, dynamic international relations, and the distinct regional entity of Southeast Asia.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken HIST4308
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Learn the history of Southeast Asia, along with Chinese migration and Western colonization development

- Learn the geographical development of different powers

- Develop writing and presentation skills through tutorials and assignments

- 學習伴隨中國移民潮和西方殖民地化演進發展的東南亞歷史；

- 學習各勢力的地區性發展；

- 透過導修和作業，鍛鍊撰述和報告的技巧。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Chinese Education in Singapore and Malaysia in the Twentieth Century
courses.description: This course aims at reviewing the development of Chinese-medium school education in Singapore and Malaysia since the twentieth century. Major topics include the relationship between overseas Chinese community and Chinese-medium school education, the British suppression over Chinese-medium schools in the post-war period, Chinese entrepreneurs and Chinese-medium schools, the linkage between political changes and Chinese-medium schools and students during the decolonization period, the rise and fall of Chinese-medium university, major changes in the policy on Chinese-medium school education in Singapore and Malaysia, the resistance of Chinese-medium school education organizations in Malaysia against the government’s education policy, and a comparison between the development of Chinese-medium school education in Singapore and Malaysia.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken HIST4311
courses.learning_outcomes:
The expected learning outcomes include:

1. The students can trace the historical development of Chinese education in Singapore and Malaysia in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

2. The students can explain how Chinese education evolved in Singapore and Malaysia in the twentieth century.

3. The students can identify major characteristics of the historical development of Chinese education in Singapore and Malaysia.

4. The students can compare and contrast similarities and differences between the historical development of Chinese education in Singapore and Malaysia.

5. The students can evaluate the historical significance of Chinese education in the history of overseas Chinese in Southeast Asia as revealed in the cases of Singapore and Malaysia.

6. The students can conduct more in-depth research on the history of Chinese education in Singapore and Malaysia with reference to their changing political, social and economic contexts from the twentieth century onwards.

本科所預期之學生學習成果，包括：
1. 學生能夠追溯新加坡及馬來西亞華文教育在19及20世紀的發展經過。

2. 學生能夠闡釋新加坡及馬來西亞華文教育在20世紀如何演變。

3. 學生能夠辨識新加坡及馬來西亞華文教育歷史發展的特色。

4. 學生能夠比較新加坡和馬來西亞兩地華文教育歷史發展過程的異同。

5. 學生能夠從新加坡及馬來西亞兩地的案例，就華文教育對東南亞華人的歷史意義作出評價。

6. 學生能夠針對新加坡和馬來西亞兩地的政治、社會及經濟等方面的背景，對兩地的華文教育歷史進行深入研究。
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Singapore, Malaysia and Chinese Education

- To introduce the course.

- To provide an overview of the historical importance of the evolution of Chinese education in Singapore and Malaysia from the end of the nineteenth century.

2. Singapore and Malaysia in the Twentieth Century

- To review the historical development of Singapore and Malaysia in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

- To highlight major historical changes in Singapore and Malaysia with reference to the development of Chinese education in both countries.

3. The Chinese Society in Singapore and Malaysia

- To identify core features of the Singapore and Malaysia-Chinese societies.

- To relate the importance of Chinese education with the core values upheld in the Singapore and Malaysia-Chinese societies with reference to such ideologies as Confucianism, patriotism, and nationalism.

4. The Origins of Chinese Education in Singapore and Malaysia

- To review how Chinese education was launched in Singapore and Malaysia.

- To explain what drove the development of Chinese education in Singapore and Malaysia after they became British colonies in Southeast Asia.

5. Chinese Organizations and Chinese Education in Singapore and Malaysia

- To highlight the close relationship between different types of Chinese organizations such as clan associations and the launch of modernized Chinese-medium school education in Singapore and Malaysia in the early twentieth century.

- To assess how significant the involvement of Chinese organizations was in the development of Chinese education in Singapore and Malaysia at the absence of the British administration’s role in financing and providing education services in both colonies.

6. Pioneer of Chinese Education in Singapore: Tan Kah Kee

- To examine the importance of Chinese entrepreneurs and philanthropists in funding Chinese education in Singapore.

- To review the life of Tan Kah Kee and to address that he was not only as a prominent Chinese entrepreneur in Singapore but also an advocate of Chinese education in Singapore and Amoy in China.

7. Chinese Education in Singapore and Malaysia, Britain and China

- To discuss how the development of Chinese education between 1900 and 1942　was affected by both the British administration and the Chinese government.

- To put an emphasis on the role of Chinese schools in the political movements in China that led to a policy shift of the British administration on handling Chinese education from a laissez-faire approach to an increasingly interventionist approach from the 1920s onwards, when Chinese education had been politicized.

8. Post-war Chinese Education and Socio-political Instability in Singapore and Malaysia

- To assess the role of Chinese schools and Chinese educated in student and labour movements in the 1950s, when both Singapore and Malaysia experienced a decade of social instability amidst the process of decolonization.

- To explain why the Singapore and Malaysian governments tended to tighten their controls over the Chinese school sector.

9. The Rise and Fall of Nanyang University

- To account for the Chinese community’s desire to set up Nanyang University in the early 1950s.

- To explain why Nanyang University could not survive as the first and only Chinese-medium university in Singapore and Malaysia.

10. Evolution of Chinese Education and Independence of Singapore and Malaysia

- To address major policy changes and their impacts on the Chinese school sectors in Singapore and Malaysia after their independence in 1965 and 1957 respectively.

- To synthesize major characteristics of Chinese education in Singapore and Malaysia after both countries became independent, and address how Chinese education was increasingly considered as an impediment to the nation-building process in both countries.

11. Chinese Education Organizations and Sim Bok Woo in Malaysia

- To identify major Chinese education organizations representing Chinese school directors and teachers in Malaysia and address how they worked to preserve the Chinese school system in the country since the 1950s, when major policy changes on the national education system had been carried out.

- To delve into the case of Sim Bok Woo to examine how Chinese community leaders in Malaysia went on their struggles with the Malaysian government in protecting the rights of Malaysian-Chinese to study in Chinese-medium schools and postsecondary education institutions.

12. A Revival of Chinese Education in Singapore and Malaysia?

- To compare and account for similarities and differences in the development of Chinese education in Singapore and Malaysia in the twentieth century.

- To discuss the growing importance of the China factor in the twenty-first century in affecting the development of Chinese education in Singapore and Malaysia.

1：新加坡、馬來西亞與華文教育

- 簡介課程。

- 概括說明華文教育演變對19世紀末期以後的新加坡和馬來西亞之歷史重要性。

2：二十世紀的新加坡及馬來西亞

- 回顧新加坡和馬來西亞在19及20世紀的歷史發展。

- 強調新加坡和馬來西亞兩地，影響華文教育發展之歷史事件。

3：新加坡及馬來西亞的華人社會

- 辨識新加坡及馬來西亞華人社會的核心特徵。

- 探討兩地的華文教育之發展，與新加坡及馬來西亞華人社會的核心價值和思想，例如儒家思想、愛國主義及民族主義的關係。

4：新加坡及馬來西亞華文教育的源起

- 回顧華文教育如何在新加坡和馬來西亞兩地創立。

- 探討使華文教育能夠在新加坡和馬來西亞成為英國在東南亞地區建立之殖民地後得以發展之原因。

5：新馬華人社團與華文教育

- 強調在新加坡和馬來西亞之各種華人團體，例如宗親會等，與現代化華文學校教育在20世紀初期之開設有密切關係。

- 針對華人社團在新加坡及馬來西亞缺乏英國殖民地政府對華文教育的財政資助情況下，其對華文教育發展之重要性作出評價。

6：新加坡華文教育的先驅：陳嘉庚

- 探討華商和慈善家對新加坡華文教育發展所扮演的角色。

- 透過回顧陳嘉庚的生平事蹟，突出陳氏作為新加坡首屈一指的企業家以外，亦是新加坡和中國廈門華文教育發展的主要推動者。

7：新馬華文教育、英國及中國

- 討論1900至1942年期間，兩地的華文教育發展，如何受到英國殖民地政府及中國政府和政治發展的影響。

- 強調華文學校在參與中國有關的政治活動，而且趨於政治化，成為英國殖民地政府改變其對華文教育發展採取的自由放任之取態，演變為從20世紀20年代開始，強化其對華文教育發展的干預。

8：戰後華文教育與新馬的政治動盪

- 探究戰後華文學校與華校生參與20世紀50年代在新加坡和馬來西亞發生的學生與工人運動，使兩地在去殖民地化的過程中，面對社會穩定受到衝擊的問題。

- 解釋新加坡和馬來西亞政府何以對華文學校體系加強管制。

- 探討為何華人社群在20世紀50年代初有意成立南洋大學。

- 闡釋作為新加坡及馬來西亞地區之首間及唯一以華語文作教學語言的南洋大學不能夠生存。

10：新馬獨立與華文教育的變遷

- 討論新加坡和馬來西亞分別於1965年和1957年獨立後，政府對華文學校體系之政策變化及其影響。

- 歸納華文教育在新加坡和馬來西亞獨立後之發展特徵，並探討華文教育何以被兩地政府視為建國過程中的主要障礙。

11：馬來西亞華校組織：董總、教總及沈慕羽

- 辨別馬來西亞自20世紀50年代以後，主要代表華校董事和教師之團體，並針對在馬來西亞獨立後建構國家教育系統之時所引發教育政策變化，其對維護華校體系所發揮的作用。

- 透過沈慕羽的生平，深入探討馬來西亞華人社會如何與當地政府抗爭，藉以保障馬來西亞華人在華語學校和專上院校接受教育。

12：新馬華文教育的復興？

- 比較華文教育在20世紀新加坡和馬來西亞兩地發展之異同。

- 討論21世紀中國因素備受重視，何以影響華文教育在新加坡和馬來西亞之發展。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The Philippines and Trans Pacific Connections
courses.description: HIST3375 offers an examination of the evolution of Philippine society from the onset of Spanish colonization in the mid-1500s to the start of World War Two in Asia (in 1941). Granting an opportunity to grasp the development of the Philippines under Spanish, American, and Japanese colonial rule, the course places attention upon the nation’s capital city, Manila, a place where life has also been historically shaped by Chinese, Japanese, Western, and native cultural influences. Focusing on elements of cultural, political, and urban history the course endeavours to explain how ‘the Philippine nation’ has historically unfolded, and why Manila, today a metropolis with a population in excess of 13 million people, has come to play such a dominant role in determining the nature of Philippine society prior to the country being granted independence in 1946. Utilizing innovative teaching methods to enable students to critically understand the physical as well as cultural character of the city, and so the nation at large, a multidisciplinary approach is fostered so as to encourage learners to recognize and explain factors that have influenced Philippines civilization as it progressed from the “traditional” to the “modern”. Encouraging learners too to identify connections between the country and places elsewhere in the Asia-Pacific region, ultimately the course places the evolution of life in the Philippine Archipelago within the greater Asia-Pacific region. Accordingly, the curriculum is cut into two distinct sections: The Philippines pre-1898; and, the Philippines post-1898. Where possible a comparative analysis with the colonial development of Hong Kong will be provided so as to demonstrate, and explain, the different types and natures of colonial rule, culture, and development that took place in East Asia prior to the end of World War Two.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Traditional Japan
courses.description:
This course introduces the Japanese tradition from late 8th century to mid-nineteenth centuries. Students will learn how the “Japanese-ness” developed in the Edo closed foreign policy, and how and why some traditions still survive today.
In each lecture, one traditional form of arts, crafts, ritual, festival or lifestyle is introduced, with its historical background. How did the tradition start, transformed, sustained or disappeared? What are the interpretation, image and importance of tradition in contemporary world, and why? The course aims to analyze Japanese culture and society through examining the historical development of tradition.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken HIST3213 and HIST5507F.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Understand the transformation of Japanese traditional culture before the Meiji Restoration / Westernisation

- Gain the knowledge on Japanese study resources

- Develop the comparative view on traditional and imported cultures in the historical context

- Train the research, academic writing and editing skill through reading and essay assignments

- 明瞭明治維新或西化時期以前日本傳統文化的變革；

- 汲取有關日本研究資訊的知識；

- 養成對悠久歷史背景下的傳統的、外來的諸種文化的比較視野；

- 透過閱讀和論文作業，鍛鍊研究、撰寫和改訂學術著作的技巧。

courses.title: History of Modern Japan
courses.description: It is important to understand the emergence of Japan from a relatively isolated feudal society into the second largest economic power in the world after the US. It is the only society that successfully modernized prior to the 1970’s, and it is the only country in Asia that belongs to the G7. It has had a significant economic impact upon its neighbors as well as the world.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students at the end of the term are expected to have an educated understanding of modern Japan, its history, society and people and its relevance to us as residents of Hong Kong. Such an understanding is important in today’s global environment particularly Japan is not only a geographical neighbor but also one of our most important trading partners.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: War and Society (1000-1900)
courses.description: This course studies how societies make war and how war affects societies. The focus is not so much about military strategy, but more on the interaction among wars, technological innovation and institutional evolution. It mainly studies wars in Chinese history but will also cover non-Chinese historical episodes.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Rethinking history from the perspective of war.

- Abandon the popular obsession about military strategy, instead, develop a social-history approach to the study of war.

- Develop critical judgement on war-related issues like war and peace, war and justice, individual freedom and collective well-being, nationalism and jingoism.

- 從軍事的角度思考歷史；

- 去除對於軍事戰略的迷戀，以社會史的角度研究戰爭歷史；

- 深入思考戰爭與和平、戰爭與公義、個人自由與集體福利、民族主義與軍國主義等問題。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Food and Food Cultures
courses.description: Food is central to all societies. Given its importance, it is not surprising that the production of food, its distribution, preparation and presentation, are clothed with meaning and surrounded by ritual. Changes in food culture reflect changes in the larger culture. This course will adopt a historical approach to examine the origin and evolution of food as these meanings and uses change over time. While studying food cultures of the past, students will be encouraged to explore and analyse the food cultures of their own society.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken GESC2020
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Gain a solid training in empirical methods for the study of history

- Develop critical thinking through analysis of historical materials

- Learn basic research skills of conducting historical research and enhance writing skills.

- Enhance inter-personal skills with interviewees through oral history exercises

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: War and Society in Ancient China (from Early Period to the Sixth Century CE)
courses.description: This course aims to present and explain how war and society shaped each other in classical and early medieval China, roughly from the early period to the sixth century CE. While the interactive relations between state, society, and warfare constitute the main thread that runs through the course as a whole, this course also covers a broad range of issues, including the operation of various military institutions and their rationales; civil-military relations; political and military cultures; military thoughts, tactics, and strategy; social impact of warfare, cultural responses to military conquests; intellectual debates on statecraft; as well as interactions, especially in the military aspects, between Chinese regimes and their Eurasian neighbors.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to:

a. examine how the development of ancient Chinese civilization shaped, and was shaped by, war.

b. analyze the tension and complementarity of cultural (wen) and martial (wu) values in Chinese culture and their long-lasting impact on Chinese culture.

c. reflect the impact of war on pre-modern Chinese society and on the living of common people as well.

d. discuss the relationship between war and society of ancient China in Eurasian and comparative perspectives.

e. develop a strategic perspective of viewing historical and current issues.

學員在研習本課程後，將可具備以下知識與能力：

1. 認識傳統中國文明與戰爭的互動關係

2. 分析中國傳統文化中的文與武觀念及其對中國社會與文化的深遠影響

3. 反思戰爭的禍害及其對普遍民眾生活帶來的影響

4. 從歐亞大陸歷史發展的比較角度來了解古代中國的戰爭與社會之關係

5. 透過學習軍事史而培養以戰略思維分析事物
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Why do we study ancient Chinese warfare?

2. The state of the art in military history

3. Collective violence in early societies

4. The formation of early states and the ascendancy of aristocratic warriors

5. Sanctioned militarization of pre- and early imperial Chinese society

6. Thinking about war in a chaotic era

7. The strategic culture of early imperial China

8. Military culture and regional diversity

9. The disintegration of the Han empire and the rise of militant communities

10. Spontaneous militarization of early medieval Chinese society

11. Ethnicity and warfare

12. Religious beliefs and warfare

13. Ancient Chinese warfare in a world historical context

第一講　導論：為甚麼要研究古代戰爭？

第二講　軍事史研究的一些概念、術語及學術現況

第三講　早期社會中的集體暴力

第四講　國家的建立與貴族武裝的登場

第五講　軍國體制與全方位戰爭

第六講　亂世中對暴力的思考

第七講　帝國的戰略順序

第八講　軍事文化與地域分野

第九講　帝國崩解與武將群體的冒起

第十講　暴力橫行與軍事化措施

第十一講　胡漢問題與戰爭暴力

第十二講　宗教信仰與戰爭暴力

第十三講　世界史視野下的古代中國戰爭

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Gender and History
courses.description: This course demonstrates critically how the gender perspective as an important new academic paradigm challenges the mainstream historical analysis and explanation and influences feminist historiography. Topics may vary from year to year based on the respective teacher's research specialization in women's/Gender History of China, Asia, or the West.
courses.learning_outcomes:
修畢本科後，學生當能：
1. 認識性別史對主流歷史分析和解釋的挑戰，及對女性主義史學的影響。

2. 了解任教老師按其研究專長定出的婦女/ 性別史專題內容。

3. 掌握以上有關歷史課題的性別觀，從兩性權力關係及其歷史語境的複雜性切入，對重要問題作出批判分析。

4. 透過對有關論著的闡釋研讀，引發概念、方法、史料、論述等方面的反思。

5. 對有關歷史課題作口頭和文字報告。

6. 在作業中展示對婦女/ 性別史課題的綜合、說明和解釋能力以及研究潛力。
courses.course_syllabus:
討論重點
近年之討論重點為中國現代國家建構之性別觀，從兩性權力關係及其歷史語境之複雜性切入，對婦女在廿世紀中國現代民族國家建構過程中各階段之經驗及處境作歷史闡釋，並透過對有關論著之闡釋研讀，引發研究方法、史料、論述等方面之反思。

討論專題及閱讀材料
節數 專題
一 導論：性別與歷史研究新範式
二 婦女史與性別史之論爭
三 中國歷史之婦女史及性別史研究進路
四 中國民族主義之性別觀﹕早期中國女權運動及其男性倡導者
五 從「國民之母」到「女國民」
六 「新女性」﹕女性與新文化運動
七 現代性之性別觀：民國時期之婦女議題
八 中國革命之性別觀
九 「國家女性主義」﹕毛澤東時代之婦女
十 改革開放之性別意涵
十一 「新女性主義」前後的台灣婦女運動
十二 婦女、性別與殖民地國家及社會﹕香港一例
十三 中外學者研究方向總評

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Women, Family and Community in Western History
courses.description: This course examines the nature and significance of community and family structures in the West. A broad range of issues relating to the history of communities and families will be discussed. Particular emphasis will be placed on the ways in which community and family structures have influenced gender definitions and the assignment of gender roles, as well as how sexuality has been perceived and constrained in Western societies. The roles of western women will be discussed in different perspectives, such as political, economic, religion and social perspectives.

Lecture 3. Women in ancient Rome

Lecture 4. Christianity and women

Lecture 7. Early modern household and community

Lecture 8. The margin of society: witch hunts

Lecture 9. Women in enlightenment

Lecture 10. Women and education: The Blue Stockings

Lecture 11. Women’s suffrage movement

Lecture 12. Women and communism

Lecture 13. Conclusion: Gender movement since 1960s

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Museum and Heritage
courses.description: This course reviews the historical development of concepts and theories related to museums and cultural heritage. It introduces diversified definitions of museums and heritage in the contemporary. Through selected case studies and field trips, it demonstrates the operations of museums and heritage sites; and analyses their social roles in modern society. Reviewing the historical evolution of international conventions related to museums and heritage outlines how vital international and regional cooperation is for sustainable heritage conservation and management.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students should understand core concepts and theories related to museums and heritage in the contemporary world.

2. Students should learn about the historical development of museums and heritage.

3. Students shall develop their capacity to review the social roles of museums and heritage in contemporary society.

4. Students shall be able to outline the importance of international and regional cooperation on issues related to heritage conservation.
