4. 學生應能勾勒國際及地區性合作對於文化遺產保育的重要性。
courses.course_syllabus:
Section 1: Concepts and theories related to museums and heritage

1. The origin of the museum and its historical development.

2. Core concepts related to museum curation and artefact management.

3. The history of the museums in East Asia, including mainland China and Hong Kong.

4. The concepts and definitions of cultural heritage and their historical evolution.

5. The understandings and interpretation of cultural heritage in East Asian context.

Section 2: The social roles of museums and heritage and their public engagement

1. The transformation of the social roles of museums and heritage.

2. The educational functions of museums and heritage.

3. The social inclusion of museums and heritage.

4. The reuse and revitalisation of heritage in modern society.

Section 3: Achieving sustainable heritage conservation and management through International and regional cooperation

1. International conventions related to heritage conservation and management.

2. The modus operandi of UNESCO World heritage and its sustainable development goals.

3. The challenges and opportunities of international and regional cooperation regarding heritage conservation and management.

第一部：博物館及文化遺產的概念和理論

1. 博物館概念的源起、發展和擴充。

2. 博物館策展以及文物展示的基本概念和知識。

3. 東亞地區包括中國內地和香港博物館的發展歷史。

4. 文化遺產概念的源起及發展。

5. 東亞地區對於文化遺產概念的理解和演繹。

第二部：博物館及文化遺產的社會角色與公眾參與

1. 博物館及文化遺產社會角色的歷史演變。

2. 博物館及文化遺產的教育功能和角色。

3. 博物館及文化遺產與不同社群公眾的關係和連結。

4. 文化遺產在當代社會的活化和再利用。

第三部：國際及地區性合作與可持續的文化遺產管理

1. 有關文化遺產保育和管理的國際性公約和守則。

2. 聯合國世界文化遺產的運作及管理機制；以及其可持續發展目標。

3. 國際及地區性合作在文化遺產保育上所面對挑戰及機遇。

courses.description: This course examines the historical background, characteristics, theories and themes of ancient Greek and Chinese Mythology from a comparative perspective.

By the end of the course, students will be able to have

1. a better understanding of the theories and themes of comparative mythologies, especially those in ancient Greece and China;
2. critically thought about related issues of mythology;
3. gained a basic understanding of comparative mythology of the world as a whole.

- 培養終身學習興趣

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Revolutions: East and West
courses.description: This is a team-taught course exploring major revolutions in East and West since the eighteenth century. Different perspectives on the various resolutions will be examined, as well as comparisons and contrasts among the chosen revolutions. The lectures will introduce students to the types of questions historians ask, as well as to the multiple and often contradictory answers which different historians offer to these questions. The contents may vary from year to year.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Deepening the understanding of history through primary sources

- Developing critical thinking through analysis of historical materials on the revolutions of different countries

- Compare the essence of historical studies of different countries

- Learning basic skills in writing history research reports and enhancing writing ability.

- Cultivating an interest in engaging in historical research in the future

- 透過原始資料加深對歷史的認識

- 透過分析不同國家的革命史料建立批判思維

- 比較對不同國家的歷史研究的精粹

- 學習撰寫歷史研究報告的基礎知識從而改善寫作能力

- 培養學生將來研究歷史的興趣

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History, Memory, and Monuments
courses.description: History, Memory, and Monuments offers a new frame for learners to expand their comprehension of how historical knowledge is formed, and how it is consumed within the arena of public spaces and the viewing of monument. In particular, the course examines how monuments/heritage sites, alongside museums, etc., function as gatekeepers of historical knowledge and as channels of social memory. The course, thus, breaks down dynamics (both local and global) that contribute to public debate about the past. In amalgamating knowledge of representations of the past with the development of skills in historical methodology, theory, and practice, students can expand cognisance as to how public history is represented, constructed, debated and, at times, contested. By possessing new critical awareness and skills students will be better able to sense and value the variety of roles played by historians in public settings, and the significance and impact too of public history upon culture, politics, and society at large.

- Acquire solid training in the craftsmanship of historiographical writing;

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Western Historiographical Tradition
courses.description: This course examines vital concepts and evolving intellectual orientation of Western historical understanding and writing from classical times to the present.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, students should be able to achieve the following objectives:

- Gain a solid training in the craftsmanship of academic presentation and historiographical writing;
- Identify, understand, and critically analyze major schools of thoughts in Western historiography;
- Demonstrate profound understanding and critical analysis of various historical archives.

同學修畢此課程，當可達到以下學習目標：
- 在寫作歷史學論文方面得到扎實的訓練；

- 辨別、理解、深入分析西方史學的各主要學派；

- 充分掌握及分析各種史料。
courses.course_syllabus:
Herodotus (480-420 B.C.) has been called “the father of history” in the West for 2500 years. But he is becoming even more fashionable in our postmodern age for the reason that his The History is being involved in the contemporary debates and controversies on the topics of Orientalism, multiculturalism, and the New Historicism. Some believe The History is the very first file in the archive of Orientalism, the discourse by which the European imagination has dominated the non-European Other by conceptualizing its inhabitants as barbarians. Others see him as the very first multiculturalist because he inquires into so many different peoples and cultures: Lydians, Persians, Babylonians, Egyptians, Scythians, Libyans…

In this course, we will read The History from the beginning to the end in order to understand how Herodotus views or constructs “Others” (non-Greeks) — and how, by doing so, he constructs the identity of his own people, the Greeks.

- Introduction: the Representation of Foreign Peoples

- The Rise and Fall of Lydia

- Gyrus and the Rise of the Persian Empire

- Egypt

- Darius and the Persian Empire

- Scythia

- Greeks and Persians

- Marathon

- Xerxes and the Persian Invasions of Greece

- Salamis

- Athens, Sparta, and Persia

- From the Persian Empire to the Athenian Empire

二千五百年以來，希羅多德(480-420 B.C.)被譽為西方「史學之父」。今天，西方史學界不僅沒有厭棄希羅多德，反而對希羅多德興趣日濃。本課程把希羅多德的名著《歷史》從頭到尾認真研讀，嘗試理解希羅多德如何看待希臘以外的「他者」、並如何因此建構自己即希臘人的身份認同。

- 序論：希羅多德筆下的外人

- 利迪亞(Lydia)的興亡

- 波斯帝国的盛衰

- 埃及

- 大流士(Darius)與波斯帝國

- 斯基太(Scythia)

- 希臘與波斯

- 馬拉松(Marathon)

- 波斯侵略希臘

- 薩拉米斯(Salamis)

- 雅典、斯巴達克、波斯

- 從波斯帝國到雅典帝國

- Grasp presentation skills through discussion in tutorials.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Material Culture in Ancient China
courses.description:
This course presents a comprehensive introduction to Pre-Han China focusing on thrilling archaeological discoveries. The course places emphasis on social, political and economic aspects of ancient China and major social transitions reflected in material cultures in order to complement the missing of textual records. We will examine a variety of themes through the lens of material culture engaged with primary and secondary textual sources. We cover the period between the transition of Neolithic and early domestication until the end of the Qin Empire. The main focus is on understanding how we can reconstruct various aspects of ancient China through the analysis and interpretation of material culture.
Important themes covered in the class include the origin and foundation of early civilization, the formation of early state, urbanism, divination and state-sponsored ritual, trade and core-periphery relations, craft industry and technological change, the emergence of state bureaucracies, and the process of political unification. The course will provide students a basic understanding of these topics in the contexts of early China as understand through the material culture of ancient Chinese societies in juxtaposition with early textual sources including oracle bone inscription and bronze inscriptions. Weekly tutorial sections will focus on the implications and significance of these themes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken HIST4140
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:

• Analyze the formation process of civilization and major transformative social changes in ancient China.

• Understand how archaeologists reconstruct the history of “prehistory” through archaeological records.

• Critically evaluation the strength and limitation in archaeological research.

• Discuss how archaeological records can be productively supplement textual evidence in historical research.

• Understand the legacy of big social changes and impacts of ancient China in present-day societies.

• Cultivate the abilities of cross-cultural, inter-disciplinary and critical thinking.

預期達到的教學目的包括:

- 分析早期中國文明的形成過程和重大社會轉折

- 如何以考古材料重建“史前史”

- 對考古研究優點和局限之批判性分析能力

- 在歷史學研究中如何以考古資料有效地輔助文獻研究

- 早期中國在當代社會的深遠影響

- 跨文化與跨學科之研究能力

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Ordinary Voices, Extraordinary Stories: History and Memory in Documentaries and Biographies
courses.description: This course will be an intellectual exploration of individual stories and voices, through the lenses of independent documentaries, memoires, biographies, and oral histories, in major historical events throughout the PRC period of modern Chinese history. In addition to primary sources, students would also read scholarly materials on related historical events as well as on the presentation and mis-representation of history at different periods of time both inside and outside China to develop comparative perspectives. This class is a student-centered one in the form of a flipped classroom as encouraged by the university. Students are expected to be actively engaged in class and to work with other students. Class activities include group discussions, news presentations, lectures, and documentary screenings. Both lectures and tutorial sessions will be taught by the course instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course aims to help students develop skills to think, write, and speak critically and analytically about the past. The documentaries and biographies aim to facilitate students’ understanding of history through human experiences, and to eventually cultivate students’ personal engagement as well as historical consciousness and intellectual understanding of the world. Students will learn to evaluate historical evidence in primary and secondary sources, to think within historical contexts, to recognize the historical forces at work, to identify continuities and changes, and to understand the ethical dimension of historical interpretations as world citizens.

本課程旨在培養同學對歷史事件進行批判性的分析、思考、寫作、和表達的能力。通過紀錄片與傳記裡的個人經驗而非宏大敘事促進學生對歷史事件的了解，培養歷史意識和判斷, 以及與過去和當下對話的能力。學生通過原始材料和學術討論審視歷史，在歷史背景下思考問題，認識在歷史當中各種力量的博弈，了解歷史的延續性和變化，以及學習從世界公民的價值層面來解讀歷史。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Imperial Capitals: Chang'an, Luoyang and Kaifeng (BCE 202 - 1130 CE)
courses.description: This course is a survey of the evolution of imperial capitals of Chang’an, Luoyang and Kaifeng in natural geography, city planning, metropolitan area, society, economy and military defense during a period of about one millennium from the Middle Ages to the early modern times. In particular, the ecology, topography, morphology, social structure and control, security, street and market system, industrial and commercial network, religious and cultural life of the capitals, and the interactions among them will be analyzed with a comparative approach. This course will also deal with the systems of imperial mausoleum, granary, grain transport, taxes, corvee, land tenure, administration, monitoring, traffic, boundary pass and military affairs in metropolitan areas, and the transformation of a dual capital system into a multiple capital system. Through PowerPoint lectures and interactive tutorials on these topics, students will thoroughly understand the structural transformation and relocation trend of the national capital in North China during this period. Teacher will also provide guidance in reading the related written sources and archaeological finds useful for writing the term paper.

courses.course_syllabus:
A. Topics on capitals

1. Location, ecology and topography of capitals

It analyses the basic factors affecting the location of traditional capitals, their ecology and problems of natural disasters.

2. Morphology and city planning of capitals (1)

It traces the origin of traditional capitals in China, investigates the layout of Capital Xianyang and the temporary palaces away from the capital in the Qin dynasty, and explores the transformation of morphology and city planning of the capitals of Changan, Luoyang and Kaifeng from the Han to the Song dynasty, especially the change of location of their palace cities from facing the east to facing the south.

3. Morphology and city planning of capitals (2)

It investigates the morphology and city planning of the T’ang capitals of Chang’an and Luoyang and the Song capital of Kaifeng and evaluates the impact of the T’ang capitals on the capital planning of other countries in East Asia.

4. Social structure, market system and commercial activities in capitals (1)

It explores the social structure, market system and commercial activities in Capital Luoyang in Northern Wei dynasty and Capital Chang’an in the T’ang dynasty.

5. Social structure, market system and commercial activities in capitals (2)

It explores the social structure, market system and commercial activities in Capital Kaifeng in Northern Song dynasty

6. Daily life, religion and cultural intercourse in capitals

It illustrates the food culture, sports, entertainments, international cultural exchange activities and spread of foreign religions especially Nestorianism in Capital Chang’an in the T’ang dynasty.

B. Topics on metropolitan areas

7. The origin, scope, bureaucracy, administration and monitoring of metropolitan areas (1)

It explains the demarcation of metropolitan areas by the Western Zhou dynasty which commenced the metropolitan system in China, and explores the evolution of metropolitan areas since the Qin dynasty.

8. The origin, scope, bureaucracy, administration and monitoring of metropolitan areas (2)

It explores the development of metropolitan areas in the T’ang and Northern Song dynasties and demonstrates the special bureaucracy, administration and monitoring systems in there.

9. The systems of tax, corvée and land tenure in metropolitan areas

It shows that the metropolitan areas had been establishing as both the centre of tax and corvée and the income base for the emperor and the central government officials by prohibiting migration of the registered population, feudalization and hunting in the areas, and allocating the land (rent) there to the central officials from the Western Zhou dynasty through the T’ang dynasty.

10. The post roads and boundary passes for defense in metropolitan areas

It illustrates the facilities of postal stations and the post road transport in the metropolitan areas from the Western Zhou dynasty through the Song dynasty. It particularly explores the systems of post road transport and four-side boundary passes in the east and west metropolitan areas in the Han and T’ang dynasties.

11. Temporary palaces and military affairs in metropolitan areas

It explores the history of metropolitan areas serving as the military centre of the Empire and especially the high concentration of militia units and temporary palaces in the two metropolitan areas in the Sui-T’ang dynasties.

C. Topics on capital system

12. The systems of dual capitals and multiple capitals

It examines the development of sub-capital system from the Xia dynasty to the Song dynasty and its determining factors. It particularly explores the evolution of the dual capital system to multiple capital system and the official system of branch offices in Capital Luoyang in the T’ang dynasty.

13. The relocation trend of the national capital and its determining factors

It analyses the eastward relocation trend of the national capital and its determining factors from the Sui dynasty to the Northern Song dynasty.

一. 都城篇

1. 都城之選址與生態形勢

本課分析古代都城選址的基本因素、古都的生態環境，以及都城的災害問題。

2. 都城之城郭形制與規劃結構 (1)

本課追溯中國都城的起源，考察秦都咸陽城及離宮的佈局，探討漢至宋朝的長安、洛陽、開封三都的城郭形制和規劃結構之演變，尤其西漢都城宮殿坐西朝東的形制和東漢以後宮殿坐北朝南的形制。

3. 都城之城郭形制與規劃結構 (2)

本課探討唐朝長安、洛陽兩都及宋朝開封都城的城郭形制、規劃結構，以及唐兩都對古代東亞國家的都城規劃的影響。

4. 都城之社會結構、市制及商業活動 (1)

本課分析北魏洛陽和唐代長安兩都的社會結構、市制及商業活動。

5. 都城之社會結構、市制及商業活動 (2)

本課分析北宋開封都城的社會結構、市制及商業活動。

6. 都城之生活、宗教及文化交流

本課探討唐朝長安都城市民的飲食文化、體育娛樂，以及城中的國際文化交流活動和外來宗教如景教的傳播發展。

二. 都畿篇

7. 畿內之起源、範圍演變及官僚體系和行政、監察制度 (1)

本課考察西周王畿的建立，說明中國畿內制的起源，並探討秦朝以降歷代王朝的畿內範圍之演變。

8. 畿內之起源、範圍演變及官僚體系和行政、監察制度 (2)

本課考察唐朝和北宋的畿內演變及其特殊的官僚體系和行政、監察制度。

9. 都畿之土地及賦役制度

本課說明從西周至唐朝，畿內充當天子的供御地和京官的租入地，限制所在編戶遷往畿外，常予賦役的減免優待，又禁止分封諸侯和戈獵採捕，而將土地(田租)授予京官。

10. 都畿之驛道交通與關防

本課探討西周至宋朝的畿內郵驛交通制度，尤其說明漢、唐兩朝東、西兩畿的驛道和四面關制度。

11. 都畿之離宮與軍事部署

本課考察古代王朝畿內充當軍事基地的傳統，尤其著重說明隋唐兩朝京畿所在密集的皇帝離宮和軍府部署。

三. 都制篇

12. 兩都制與數都制

本課考察上古夏朝至宋朝的陪都制度發展及相關因素，尤其深入討論隋唐兩朝從兩都制演變到數都制的發展，以及唐朝東都的分司官體制。

13. 國都的遷移趨勢及其因素

本課分析隋至宋朝期間國都東移的趨勢及其基本因素。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: A Thousand Years of Huizhou (800-1800 CE)
courses.description: This course explores the interaction of natural geography, administrative geography, socio-economic transformation and major historical events in Huizhou region in China in the last millennium.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken HIST4309
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Understand the process of the historical and cultural formation of local societies;
- Understand the interaction between natural environment and human activities;
- Acquire solid research skill for the study of special historical archives such as land deeds, local gazetteers, memorials, imperial decrees, etc..

- Develop critical insight on complex issues like relations between individuality and collectivity, between small community and larger organization, between society and state.

- 掌握地方社會的歷史發展與文化構成過程；

- 認識自然環境與人類活動的互動；

- 認識並分析地契、方志、奏摺、聖旨等各種史料；

- 對於個人與集體、小社區與大組織、社會與國家之間關係等複雜問題，產生深刻的認識。

(7) Huizhou merchants and the Ming maritime trade

(8) Huizhou merchants and salt merchants

(9) Huizhou merchants in other business sectors

(10) Migration

(11) Everyday life in Huizhou

(12) Modernity in Huizhou

(13) Conclusion

(4) 編戶齊民﹕明朝里甲制在徽州

(6) 宗族﹑階級矛盾﹑奴變

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The Industrial Revolution and Its Impacts
courses.description:
The module intends to provide a survey of the origins and transformations of industrial society over the last two centuries or so, a period of time within which industrial nation states have reached new heights of power and acquired the dominant share of the world’s wealth – a wealth once dominated by Westerners but increasingly challenged in recent years by the rise of, for example, South East Asian nations. This comparative studies programme shall allow students to obtain a critical understanding of the nature of industrial society through fostering a multidisciplinary approach to industrialisation and many of the changes in society it helped to establish. The course will give students the opportunity to consider the ideas and the conditions in Europe and elsewhere that produced industrial change, capitalism and democracy – processes that the West considered then and still considers today as desirable for itself and other parts of the world. The curriculum gives particular focus to pre-industrial Europe and its economy, industrial Britain, urbanisation and its effects upon social classes, public health, housing and ways of living. The course is designed to build skills such as thinking critically, well-constructed writing and the clear presenting of oral arguments. In so doing students will be expected to critically engage with a range of academic disciplines such as History (social and economic, cultural and urban), Social Studies, Economics and Geography, so as to answer questions such as:

• In what ways did industrialisation fundamentally change societies?
• What factors accounted for the beginning of the Industrial Revolution?
• How did patterns of urbanisation change as a consequence of industrial growth?
• How did social class relations shift due to industrial progress?
• How did industrial changes affect the role of women or children in the work place?
• What demographic changes have occurred since industrialisation began?
• Were the First and Second Industrial Revolutions the same or were they different?
• How did rural developments affect the rise of industry in Europe’s past?
• What is the relationship between cities and the countryside both before and after the onset of industrial growth?
• What dangers arise from industrial and urban transition? Are these dangers universal?
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course students should be able to achieve the following objectives:

1. Recognise and explain key events that led to upheavals within the economies and societies of Europe, North America and Asia, in so doing enhancing existing knowledge of what shaped these continents.

2. Grasp the relationship between the evolution of industrialisation and the changing nature of societies.

3. Consider broad issues within History in greater depth so as to make connections between industrial growth and other contexts.

4. Demonstrate historical knowledge via a short tutorial presentation and class-centred exercises.

5. Exhibit critical thinking and research skills through the writing of scholarly assignments and the compiling of an online portfolio.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Ancient Egypt: History, Art, Religion, and Modern Perceptions
courses.description: This course aims at two goals: to inform the students about the major aspects of the civilization of ancient Egypt, such as history, art, religion, literature, society, and to allow students to form their own idea of how our modern knowledge of ancient Egypt was formed. Thus whenever a subject is offered, students will be given the evidence, so that knowledge about the subject should be based on a conscious reflection upon available evidence and logical reasoning. In addition to knowledge of ancient Egyptian civilization, students will also learn how the study of humanity can be conducted from a historical perspective.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: West and the World I: Antiquity
courses.description: The ancient Mediterranean world (c. 800 BCE-250 CE) is often seen as the fountainhead of “Western” culture, but what was it really like? This course will have two aims: to understand the core contributions (philosophical, political, literary, etc.) of the ancient Mediterranean world to later periods of “Western” history, and to understand its relationship to the rest of the world (Han China, India, ancient Near East, etc.). To do so, we will focus on a series of “moments” (and the related sources), which either had a particular influence on later periods or display the interconnectedness of the ancient world.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken HIST4304
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Develop an understanding of the earliest period of Western history.

3. Learn to critically analyze sources and documents, and develop critical thinking skills.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The Making of the Middle East
courses.description:
The 'Middle East' is a geographical concept developed by officials in the British Empire in the 19th century to describe the lands between Europe and their distant colonies in India and East Asia. In the 21st century, we often associate the Middle East with the Muslim religion and Arab culture, but it is a vast region spanning from Morocco to India and home to countless peoples and faiths. It is the birthplace not just of Islam but also of Christianity, Judaism, and other religions, while its peoples speak not just Arabic but also Farsi, Turkish, French, and more. At its extremities, the Middle East connects China, Europe, and Africa.

This course provides a broad survey of Middle Eastern history from the last days of the ancient Roman and Persian Empires in the 6th century to the emergence of modern Middle Eastern nationalisms in the 19th. It looks at the most important themes of change and continuity in the region, examining the important historical dynamics that have made the Middle East what it is today. The course also situates its subject matter in the wider context of world history, exploring how the Middle East has affected, and been affected by, events in Europe, Africa, Asia, and even the Americas.

2. To show students how and why historians have constructed narratives around change and continuity in the Middle East.

3. To help students develop important historical skills: how to understand unfamiliar primary sources, how to think critically about historical narratives, and how to effectively communicate their analysis to others.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Traditional Chinese Festivals in Hong Kong: Perspectives of History and Anthropology
courses.description: This course attempts to study traditional Chinese festivals celebrated in the rural and urban sectors in Hong Kong from the perspectives of History and Anthropology. Our main objective is to understand how festivals, as intangible heritage, are preserved, transformed and interpreted in the rapid urbanizing/modernizing society.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Provide students a thorough understanding of Chinese intangible heritage and its adaptation and transformation under different social factors in Hong Kong.

- Through participant observation, collecting and analysing first hand resources, students are expected to master the method and theory of history and anthropology. Students are trained to conduct independent field research with historical perspective.

- Use cross-disciplinary approach, this course provides students foundations to appreciate their cultural tradition as well as the ways of living of other people.

- 讓學生全面認識在香港不同社會因素下，中國非物質文化遺產的適應與轉變。

- 透過參與觀察，收集與分析第一手資料，期望學生能掌握歷史人類學的方法與理論。訓練學生以歷史的視角獨立從事田野研究

- 利用跨學科方法，培養學生欣賞自身的文化傳統，與及別人的生活方式的基本能力。
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Theory and

1. Anthropological and historical approaches towards the study of festivals

2. Tradition and modernity: two facets of Chinese festivals

Part II: Traditional festivals in the social and cultural background of Hong Kong

3. Urban and rural sectors and their approaches towards traditional Chinese festival

4. Hong Kong, city of innovative, adaptive and traditional festivals

Part III: Festivals and society

5. Festivals of the ancestors, festivals of the descendants

6. Festivals in fisherman communities

7. Festivals of the new migrants

8. Festivals to unite, festivals to divide

Part IV: Traditional Festivals and their modern interpretations

9. Jiao festivals and ritual in Hong Kong New Territory

10. The experts of the ritual in Hong Kong New Territory

11. Orthodoxy and heterodox: The cultural interpretations of Jiao festivals

12. Living festivals: heritage, the people and the community

第一部份　理論與課題
1. 節日研究：歷史人類學的視角

2. 傳統與現代性：中國節日的兩面性

第二部份　香港的社會與文化背景下的傳統節日
3. 面對都市與鄉村不同因素的傳統中國節日

4. 傳統節日在香港城市的創新與調適

第三部份　節日與社群
5. 祖先的節日、子孫的節日

6. 漁民社區的節日

7. 移民與節日

8. 節日：統一與分歧的不同作用

第四部份　傳統節日與其現代詮釋
9. 香港新界的醮和儀式

10. 香港新界的儀式專家

11. 正統與異端: 醮的文化詮釋

12. 活的傳統節日：文化遺產、人與社區

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: A Tale of Three Cities: Hong Kong, Shanghai and Singapore
courses.description: This course examines and compares the historical development of three Asian cities - Shanghai, Hong Kong and Singapore, focusing on the impact of Western colonialism and Chinese cultural traditions on the socio-economic growth and politico-cultural transformation of the cities.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will:

(1) have gained a solid training in empirical methods for the historical studies of Shanghai, Hong Kong and Singapore

(2) have developed critical thinking in analyzing the impact of Western colonialism and Chinese traditions on the socio-economic growth and politico-cultural transformation of these cities

修讀本科後，學生當能:

(1) 掌握實證方法研習上海、香港和新加坡的歷史發展

(2) 批判思考西方殖民主義及華人傳統文化對當地工商業發展及城市政治和文化的影響

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Chinese Diaspora
courses.description: This course introduces the history and culture of Chinatowns in the World – early Chinese settlements in Southeast Asia in the “age of commerce”, Japanese international relations and the role of Nagaski Tojinmachi and Yokohama Chukagai, American railway construction work and Chinese immigrants, and the formation of the quartier Chinois of Paris after the Vietnam War. How did the role of Chinatown transformed throughout the history? What are the recent characteristics and added-value to the tradition of Chinatown today, and how are they represented? The “city within a city” will also be examined from historical and social aspects.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Understand Chinese emigration and immigration patterns

- Learn the history of Chinatown formation and tradition

- Develop writing and presentation skills through tutorials and assignments

- 瞭解中國移民出、入境的模式；

- 認識唐人街形成的歷史及其傳統；

- 透過導修和作業，鍛鍊撰述和報告的技巧。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Women, Society, and Politics in Modern China
courses.description: This course is an intellectual inquiry into woman’s lives in social, political, and cultural contexts from the period of late 19th century to the present. We will employ a hybrid chronological and thematic approach to explore the personal experience of women as well as the contexts of society and politics in different times that women lived in. We will discuss the agency of women not merely as passive observers but at times as contributors to shape history. We will read scholarly materials and examine primary sources of memoirs, autobiographies, biographies, and oral history accounts. We will focus not only on those who are known in history, but also on ordinary individuals whose lives were affected, changed, destroyed, interrupted, empowered, and inspired by the forces of history. We will examine both the powerful and the powerless, and the power of the powerless to affect their own destiny. The course will employ a flipped classroom approach with an aim to cultivate community, collaboration, and creativity. Students are also encouraged to contribute to the documentation of women in social and political condition at different periods of history.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course aims to help students develop skills to think, write, and speak critically and analytically about key aspects of women’s lives and the diverse paths they traversed in modern China from the late Qing dynasty, through the Republican era to the founding of the People’s Republic in 1949 and all the way to the present.

本課程旨在培養同學對女性在不同歷史時期，從晚清到民國，到人民共和國1949年成立，一直到現在的經歷進行分析、思考、寫作、和表達的能力。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Sino-US Relations Since 1949
courses.description: This course examines the long and curious relationship between the United States and China. The focus will be on the period after 1949, when the People's Republic of China was proclaimed. It is to examine the changing nature of the US-China relationship - arguably the most important bilateral relationship in the world — after the end of the Cold War and the impact of the 911 terrorist attacks on the US on that relationship.
courses.learning_outcomes: To help students to understand the intricate and often confusing relationship between the United States, now the world’s only superpower, and China, the world’s most populous country.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course examines the long and curious relationship between the United States and China. The focus will be on the period after 1949, when the People’s Republic of China was proclaimed. Washington continued to recognize the Republic of China on Taiwan until the late 1970s, when the U.S. formed a virtual alliance with mainland China against the Soviet Union. The end of the Cold War eroded the basis of that relationship. And the Tiananmen Square military crackdown brought to the fore the human rights situation in China, leading to an annual debate in Congress as to whether China’s most-favored-nation trading status should be renewed. More recently, incidents such as the American bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade in 1999 and the EP-3 incident of April 2001 precipitated crises in the relationship. However, the September 11 terrorist attacks on the United States provided a new rationale for the strategic Washington-Beijing relationship. What lies in the future, as the U.S. faces a rising China? And what role has trade played in the relationship? How will the bilateral relationship fare under President Barack Obama?

Lesson One:

Orientation. What do students expect from the course? How much understanding do they have of the history and background of the U.S.-China relationship? What aspects are they especially interested in?

Lesson Two:

We will do an overview of US-China relations up to the Second World War.

Lesson Three: The U.S. and the Chinese Civil War (1946-49)

Today we will discuss the Second World War, when China and the U.S. were allies, and its aftermath, when China was torn by a civil war in which the U.S. attempted to mediate. The KMT was defeated and driven into exile in Taiwan, while the People’s Republic of China was proclaimed in 1949. The U.S. was initially resigned to accepting the conquest of Taiwan by the Chinese Communists but, after the eruption of the Korean War, President Truman decided to defend Taiwan to prevent a communist sweep across Asia.

Lesson Four: U.S. Dilemma: Communists or Chiang?

The Taiwan Strait crises of 1954 and 1958. The U.S. signs a mutual security agreement with the Republic of China on Taiwan and recognizes it as the sole legal government of all China, including the mainland. In the mean time, it holds talks with the Chinese Communist government in ambassadorial-level talks in Warsaw. This state of affairs continues until 1971, when Henry Kissinger paid a secret visit to Beijing.

Lesson Five: The Nixon Breakthrough

President Nixon makes history by going to China and signing the Shanghai Communiqué with Premier Zhou Enlai in 1972. By 1979, the U.S. reverses its position on China, signing a second communiqué normalizing relations and recognizing Beijing as the legal government while breaking off relations with the ROC on Taiwan. However, it insists on continuing to sell arms to Taiwan to help the island defend itself. Reluctantly, Deng Xiaoping agrees. But in 1982 China and the U.S. sign a third communiqué under which the U.S. agrees to gradually reduce both qualitatively and quantitatively the sale of arms to Taiwan.

Lesson Six: U.S., China and the Soviet Union; Trade grows

Throughout the seventies and eighties, the U.S. and China coordinate their moves vis-a-vis the Soviet Union. In the mean time, trade between the two countries, which was significant only in a symbolic, political sense in the early days, begins to take off and assumes an importance of its own.

Lesson Seven: Tiananmen Square, 1989

Tiananmen Square. The weeks of massive protest by pro-democracy students in the middle of Beijing culminated in the dispatch of PLA tanks and troops. Many Americans identified with the student movement and were horrified to see troops battling unarmed demonstrators. This marks a turning point in the relationship. The end of the Cold War also undermines the raison d'etre of the relationship. Congress becomes increasingly assertive where China policy is concerned.

Lesson Eight: U.S. precipitates crisis by giving Lee visa

Clinton links most-favored-nation trading status to human rights in his first year as president, but backs down after that. Under pressure by Congress, he agrees to give Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui a visa so he can go to Cornell, where Lee earned his doctorate in agricultural economics. This precipitates a huge protest by China and leads to missile tests in the Taiwan Strait in 1995 and military exercises the following year, coinciding with Taiwan’s first direct presidential elections. Clinton sends two aircraft carrier groups into vicinity of Taiwan and the U.S. and China glower at each other while standing on the brink of war.

Lesson Nine: Embassy Bombing and “2 States Theory”

The American bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, which Washington claimed was accidental, precipitates another crisis in 1999. The bombing triggers off anti-American riots in Beijing. Other events that strained the relationship during that period were the Cox report, accusing China of spying and theft of U.S. secrets, the arrest and trial of Wen Ho Lee and Lee Teng-hui’s “two states theory.” On the positive side of the ledger was agreement on China’s membership in the World Trade Organization.

Lesson Ten: The George W. Bush Presidency

Ten weeks after George W. Bush assumed the presidency, a collision between a Chinese military jet and a U.S. intelligence gathering EP3 plane precipitated another crisis in the relationship. China insisted on an American apology and detained the American crew on Hainan, an act which in the U.S. was seen as hostage taking. The second Bush administration had assumed office determined to take a stronger stance against China and in favor of Taiwan. With the dissolution of the Soviet Union, members of the Bush administration saw China as the next enemy.

Lesson Eleven: War on Terror and the Impact on China

The September 11 terrorist attack on the United States changed the course of history and forced Washington to focus on terrorism rather than on China. In China, Jiang Zemin gave up the position of party leader to Hu Jintao in 2002 and of president in 2003, but retained the position of chairman of the Central Military Commission until 2004 in the first peaceful transition of power in recent Chinese history.

Lesson Twelve: China’s Changing Role in the World

The post-911 relationship between the two countries improved greatly, with China cooperating with the U.S. in the war on terror. China did not protest as the U.S. moved into Afghanistan and other countries on China's periphery. On the North Korean nuclear issue, China began to play an increasingly pivotal role, hosting first three party and later six party talks. What does the future hold?

Lesson Thirteen: The Obama administration and U.S.-China Security/Economic Issues

The global financial crisis has captured the attention of leaders around the world, including in Washington and Beijing. To what extent was this precipitated by the trade imbalance, with China having enjoyed a huge trade surplus for many years? Is China responsible for America’s economic ills? With the Democrats now in control of both the White House and the Congress, the forces of protectionism in the U.S. are gaining strength. But the U.S. knows that it needs Chinese cooperation on a slew of major issues, ranging from North Korea to Iran to global warming and climate change.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Study of Emigrant Communities
courses.description: This course examines the interactive relations between the Chinese overseas and their hometowns from the 19th century. It attempts to investigate the factors that facilitate overseas migration, the changing perceptions of the Chinese overseas on their hometowns, their contributions towards the promotion or restriction of local modernization and the emigrant communities' "overseas connections" as cultural capital in the shaping of local politics as well as social and economic lives. This course is divided into two parts. The first part, from a macro perspective, discusses the history of the Chinese overseas migration through an analysis of the business and migration environment and the social and economic foundations of the South China communities from the Ming Qing to the Republican period. The second part, from a micro perspective, examines selected emigrants communities, their social and cultural changes in relation to their overseas connections. Lectures in the classroom will be supplemented by participant observations in the field and subsequent discussion sessions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- As part of the Department’s public and comparative history curriculum, this course provides students with an alternative interpretation on the development of China and the Chinese overseas in the Modern period.

- Students will understand the foundation, operation, organization and changes of Chinese local societies and their interaction with the State and global communities from a cross-disciplinary perspective.

- Students are expected to construct their own analysis framework which, hopefully, could be applied into their daily activities.

- 作為本系的公眾及比較歷史的課程，本課提供學生對近代中國和海外華人社會發展的一個新的認識

- 從跨學科的視角，幫助學生理解中國地方社會的基本建構、運作、組織和變遷，以及地方社會和國家的互動關係

- 幫助學生建立自身的分析框架，並且可以運用到日常活動之中
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction: themes and issues

History, society and culture of the emigrant communities in Southern China

Sino-foreign relationship and the push and pull forces of migration

Imperial perspectives and overseas migration: pirates, merchants, coolies and contract labors

Family, lineage and women: power structure and voices in the emigrant communities

Politics and overseas relations in the emigrant communities

Business and investment: charity and exploitation

Hometown connection: interactive relations of migrants and their home town

Festivals and rituals: negotiation of modernity and tradition in the emigrant communities

Information and communication: remittance, magazines and newslettes

Imagining homeland: construction of pseudo lineage

Emigrant communities as cultural resources

導論: 課題與討論

華南僑鄉的歷史、社會與文化

家庭、宗族與婦女：僑鄉的權力結構與聲音
僑鄉的政治與海外關係
商業與投資：慈善與剝削
家鄉聯繫：移民與故鄉的互動關係
節日與儀式：僑鄉的近代與傳統的協商
資訊和交流：僑批、僑刊與鄉訊
家鄉的想像：虛擬宗族的建構
作為文化資源的僑鄉

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Perspectives in Comparative and Public History
courses.description: The course is a required course of the Programme. It examines the principles and methods governing the study of comparative history and public history. It is a team-teaching course, the focuses of which will be decided by the teachers who participate in the teaching each year.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Comparative & Public History
courses.learning_outcomes:
- learn about the basic characteristics and major trends in Public and Comparative History;
- learn about a variety of approaches and methodologies, through discussion on exemplary works and relevant readings in these two areas.

- 學習比較史及公眾史兩大史學範疇的基本特色與發展趨勢
- 學習研究比較史及公眾史的途徑和方法
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Origin and Characteristics of Programme, Course Mechanics
2. Comparative History: Background and State of the Field
3. Public History: Definitions, Development and Rising Significance
4. Topics in Comparative History I: Europe and China – Marco Comparisons
5. Topics in Comparative History II: Modernization and East Asia
6. Topics in Comparative History III: Impact of Colonialism on Asian Cities – Singapore, Hong Kong and Shanghai
7. Topics in Comparative History IV: Walls and Waters – Comparing City Cultures in Shanghai and Hong Kong
8. Topics in Public History I: Memories and Monuments – Records, Archives, and Buildings
9. Topics in Public History II: Heritage and Legends – Yi He Xuan and Tung Wah
10. Topics in Public History III: History in the Field – Excursion and Observation
11. Topics in Public History IV: History Within the Walls – Museum Studies
12. Conclusions
一、 導言：設立本課程的緣起、及課程之設計和特色
二、比較史學：背景，特徵，及其流傳
三、公眾史學：定義，範圍，及其發展
四、比較史學專題I：歐洲與中國、世界文化之宏觀比較
五、比較史學專題II：近代東亞現代化之比較—中、日、韓
六、比較史學專題III：英國殖民主義對亞太城市影響之比較—沪、港、新
七、比較史學專題IV：城牆與海水：城市文化之比較：京、沪、港
八、公眾史學專題I：記錄，文獻與檔案
九、公眾史學專題II：地標和記憶：怡和軒與東華
十、 公眾史學專題III：田野考察和歷史現場
十一、公眾史學專題IV：博物館與牆壁內的歷史
十二、結語

(5) Development of firearms

courses.title: Pearl River Delta 1368-1911
courses.description: The course introduces, in the Ming and Qing periods, how local society in the Pearl River Delta was integrated into the Chinese state through a series of changes that involved constant redefinition of lineages, territories, and ethnic identities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all PG prog in Division of History
courses.learning_outcomes:
To learn about the historical development of Pearl River Delta from the Song dynasty to the Republic；
To learn to combine field work experience with documentary research in understanding local history;
To appreciate that ethnic and local identities, such as Yao, Miao, Hakka or boat people, were constructed in historical contexts;
To be sensitive to how, in different historical periods, local societies negotiated with government agencies in the implementation of financial, cultural, educational policies, and how such negotiations contributed to ethnic and local identities.

1 瞭解自宋至民國時期珠江三角洲的歷史發展，從長時段的角度看歷史；
2 學習結合田野資料和體驗，解讀特定地點的歷史資料；
2 通過對地方社會中人群的不同身份討論，瞭解身份的形成與變動是一個歷史過程。
3 瞭解不同時期，地方社會如何與政府制度打交道，比如財政、文化、教育等等。這個過程如何影響族群與身份認同。

courses.title: Commerce and Society in China 1368-2000
courses.description: The course introduces the commercial development in China between 1368 and 2000, with an emphasis on the interactions between commerce and society.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all PG prog in Division of History
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) As part of the Department’s public and comparative history curriculum, this course provides students with an alternative interpretation on the development of business and its impact on the society from the Ming dynasty to the Modern period.
(2) Students will understand the foundation, operation, organization and changes of Chinese business institutions and firms, and their interaction with the State and global communities from a cross-disciplinary perspective.
(3) Students are expected to construct their own analysis framework which, hopefully, could be applied into their daily activities.

（1）作為比較及公眾史學文學碩士課程的一部分，本課程提供學生一個明白明、清以至當代中國商業和社會之間的互動關係。
（2）學生可以從跨學科的視角，理解中國商業制度和機構的建立、運作、組織和變遷。同時理解其與國家及環球世界的互動關係。
（3）學生修畢本科，可以建立其自身的分析能力和框架，從而應用到日常生活之中

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Antiquities and Monuments in Hong Kong
courses.description: The course aims at introducing the concepts, principles, current situation, difficulties and skills of heritage conservation, as well as the values and roles of heritage in the study of local history. The course will illustrate the development of Hong Kong's 6,000 years of history through the rich and varied local tangible and intangible heritage. Emphasis will be put on the origins, development and historical significance of local archaeology, historic environment and buildings as well as intangible cultural heritage. The course will also analyse the relationship between urban planning and heritage conservation, the current heritage conservation policy, work and future strategies of Hong Kong. Heritage conservation of the Mainland and selected overseas countries, as well as the international efforts and achievements in the field will also be discussed. The course is designed and conducted by an experienced local heritage conservationist. Apart from lectures, the course includes field studies. The course is suitable for students who are interested in joining heritage conservation work and interested in local history, culture and cultural heritage.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all PG prog in Division of History
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) To introduce to students the concepts of heritage conservation.
(2) To allow students to understand the relationship between urban planning and heritage conservation.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Science and Civilization in Early China: Lithic and Jade Technology
courses.description: The history of technology is one of the important components of civilization; it is also the main impetus to its development. In particular, ancient Chinese technology has made vital contributions to the world civilization. This course will include lectures, jades manufacture experiment and examination, also, archaeological sites and museum visit. It is aimed at introducing the process and features of the formation of human lives and civilization in China and East Asian region through the history of lithic and jade technology.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all PG prog in Division of History
courses.learning_outcomes:
Deepen students' understanding of Science and Civilization in Early China
Build up learning interest as a lifelong process
Develop critical thinking through analysis on historical materials

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Cross-Strait Relations in International and Historical Perspectives
courses.description: This course examines the history of the relationship between Taiwan and mainland China since the end of World War II, when Taiwan ceased to be a Japanese colony. The victory of the Communists in China's civil war in 1949 and the relocation of the Kuomintang Government to Taipei sparked off the dispute over Taiwan's status, which endures to the present day. Now President Chen Shui-bian wants to redefine Taiwan's status as a sovereign, independent country whose name is the Republic of China, while Beijing defines Taiwan as part of China. This course will examine the stand taken on Taiwan by key international actors, in particular the United States, but including Japan and the European Union. It will look at the Taiwan Straits military crises of the 1950s and the role of the United States, the initial strong international support for the KMT government as the sole legal government of all China until the tide turned in 1971, with Beijing replacing Taipei in the United Nations. It will also examine various international documents that have a bearing on the international status of Taiwan as well as statements issued by the government in Taiwan and leading political parties there as well as white papers on Taiwan issued by the People's Republic of China.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Festival and Popular Religion in Modern China
courses.description: This course attempts to understand Modern Chinese local societies’ social structure, principles of organization, ethnic relations and process of social change through an analysis and interpretation of festivals and popular religion. The course is divided into two parts: the first part, from a macro perspective, discusses the “position” of festivals and popular religion in the Chinese Imperial State and local society. We will try to discuss (1) how did the Ming Qing Government sanction and control local ritual activities? (2) How did different social groups depict festivals and popular religion in different periods of time? And (3) How did local society utilize the State language to enhance, adjust, reconstruct and forget local traditions? The second part, through case studies, will investigate local social activities’ organizational method and its changes in order to understand the interactive relationship between tradition and modernization. It also attempts to explore the relationship between historical narration and interpretation from analyses of these case studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all PG prog in Division of History
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, the students should be able to understand Modern Chinese local societies' social structure, principles of organization, ethnic relations and process of social change through an analysis and interpretation of festivals and popular religion.

courses.title: A History of Republic of China
courses.description: The course presents the history of the Republic of China from 1912 to 1949 based on archival materials and recent studies published both in China and in the outside world. This course first reviews the current status and development of the field and then introduces some important themes and issues for analysis and discussion.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all PG prog in Division of History
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to better understand this important historical era, and acquire the basic skills of how to write dissertation with historical records and documents.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Archives and Hong Kong Historical Studies
courses.description: Archives are the most important information on historical research. However, archives were mainly used in the studying of political history in the past. In the twentieth century, historians have extensively used archival records in social and cultural history and gotten fruitful results. This course begins with the introduction of the research in this area. It also introduces the archives of the British colonial governance in Hong Kong and discusses how to use the archives in the research of Hong Kong History. Since the nineteenth century, Guangdong, Hong Kong, and Macao have developed a close connection in terms of politics, economy, society and culture; therefore, this course not only focuses on the archives in Hong Kong, but also introduces the collections of archives in Guangdong and Macao.

courses.title: Land Administration and Practice in Hong Kong
courses.description: Land administration is the key to understand a local society. The land law in Hong Kong is consisted of two parts: (i) the application of common law on Hong Kong island and Kowloon peninsula; and (ii) the use of the Great Qing Code in the New Territories (the broad sense of the New Territories including New Kowloon). However, after the Hong Kong government has implemented the “Small House Policy” since 1972, the so-called “New Territories” does include New Kowloon. This course introduces land administration of Hong Kong (Hong Kong island, Kowloon peninsula, New Territories) from the Qing dynasty up to the present time, and how the land administration affects the livelihood of common people. With regard to basic references, the course uses Hong Kong colonial files as well as the Great Qing Code, but supplemented them with lawsuit judgments and scholarly studies.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The Common People of Modern China
courses.description: This course is designed to explore the concept, the image and the livelihood of the “common people” from the last decades of the Qing dynasty to the 1940s. This era saw great changes of social and political theory: a ritual life that had reached from emperor into villages came to be articulated in relation to a central government and its cities. The rural population ceased to be central to ritual life and came to be marginalized. Orthodox values came to be looked upon as superstition. Meanwhile, a social ethos came to represent the fashion of a new age, and city life was looked upon as a symbol of progress. This transition from old to new repositioned the individual, family, nation, and even language and gender. This transition has continued to the present day, making us as much its creator as well as its product. This course seeks to raise questions about the society which we take for granted and in which we are now placed has evolved from the late Qing.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all PG prog in Division of History
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To become aware of the tenuousness of the idea of a “common people”
2. To apply historican knowledge to common beliefs associated with life styles that are often taken for granted.
3 To appreciate that as ideas were articulated in words, life styles were attached to them and became subjects of emulation.

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The Historical Anthropology of Chinese Society
courses.description: For a long time, historians and anthropologists have recognized that, despite its unity, Chinese society embodies regional social and cultural variations. To understand how Chinese society became a unity, it is necessary to trace the processes by which multiple rituals and customs converged so that they integrated with dynastic traditions. Those processes included the expansion of the imperial state from the Song dynasty to the Republic as well as the reactions of local societies to it. By combining field work and documentary analysis, this course sensitizes students to a history from below in which indigenous communities utilizes state rituals to express their own concerns and identities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all PG prog in Division of History
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To sensitise students to major concepts in the making of Chinese society.

2. To familiarize students with the combination of field experience and documentary research as an approach to

understanding Chinese history.

3. To contextualize major concepts in Chinese society to specific texts, images, architectural style, legends and rituals,

so that students may reconstruct the history behind their emergence and application.

4. To introduce students to the idea that “history” appears not only in words, but also through many other forms of

expression..

1 本課程從中國人習以為常的描述地方社會的概念開始，通過講解，讓學生明白這一類的概念是不同時期被發明和創造出來的傳統，有一個歷史過程。比如大家都有祖先，但是普通人能在祠堂祭祖並不是那麼久遠的事情，大致在明代中期以後。在中國許多地方，可能更為晚近。我們通過瞭解這個過程，探討地方社會如何利用禮儀來與國家互動等問題。

2 注重田野與文獻的結合。討論如何將書寫文獻與神明形象、建築形式、口述故事以及儀式展演等田野史料結合，進行研究。

3本課程希望在結束的時候，讓學生明白歷史並不是只有單一的敘述方式，而是有多重的聲音。希望能將歷史帶入他們的生活，也希望他們能尋找出活的歷史。

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Patterns in Urban History and Development
courses.description: This module provides an introductory survey of the history of urban development from the ancient period to the end of the twentieth century. It focuses on the forces that have led to the development of cities in the past, and achieves this through the lens of a multi-disciplinary perspective and the utilisation of various methodologies. Such a standpoint is adopted in order to allow for the exploration of the impacts of matters like politics, economics, culture and identity, art and architecture, intellectual thought, law, transportation, and military technology upon urban society at different times in history, and to recognise how they influenced the design and shape of the built environment, and so city living. Central to the programme is the use of comparative analyses which assist in identifying and contrasting patterns of urban change. As such differences in urban design that became evident in the past will be made clear. Furthermore such an approach helps illuminate and clarify the imprint upon urban space and the urban mind of agents affecting the urban development process, including visions and concepts (built and unbuilt) that have swayed social development. Importantly too in utilising this analytical perspective students are granted opportunities to test hypotheses under the guidance of their teacher about the causes and effects of urban transition, in so doing helping explicitly comprehend the narrative of historical urban development in both factual and conceptual terms.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all PG prog in Division of History
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To develop an understanding of the causes of urban development and the various agents that act upon cities (e.g. cultural, social, environmental, economic, legal, etc.) so as to expand already held knowledge about urban places across the world.
2. To recognise the relationship between the evolution of the design of urban settlements and the nature of societies.
3. To know how and why various contexts affect the shape and appearance of urban places within distinct historical periods.
4. To train to see and read urban places through the use of maps and various visual sources in order to recognise distinct architectural and urban design styles belonging to particular eras of the past.
5. To demonstrate historical knowledge via a small tutorial presentation.

courses.title: China and The West

meetings.location: Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall1

courses.description: This course studies the formation and transformation of late imperial Chinese diplomatic system. It examines how China established and maintained the tributary system, or the so-called Pax Sinica in East Asia from the 14th to the 19th century. It analyzes the complex process, starting in mid-19th century, in which China gradually accepted a new international order based on the assumption of nation-state and governed by Western international law.

\* Guo Songtao's embassy to Europe based on his diary (1877-1878)

\* Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895)

\* The Boxer Uprising (1900-1901)

\* And other important wars, diplomatic disputes, and political and economic crises in late Qing

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Study of Emigrant Communities
courses.description:
This course examines the interactive relations between the Chinese overseas and their hometowns from the 19th century. It attempts to investigate the factors that facilitate overseas migration, the changing perceptions of the Chinese overseas on their hometowns, their contributions towards the promotion or restriction of local modernization and the emigrant communities’ “overseas connections” as cultural capital in the shaping of local politics as well as social and economic lives.
This course is divided into two parts. The first part, from a macro perspective, discusses the history of the Chinese overseas migration through an analysis of the business and migration environment and the social and economic foundations of the South China communities from the Ming Qing to the Republican period. The second part, from a micro perspective, examines selected emigrants communities, their social and cultural changes in relation to their overseas connections.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all PG prog in Division of History
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) As part of the Department’s public and comparative history curriculum, this course provides students with an alternative interpretation on the development of China and the Chinese overseas in the Modern period.
(2) Students will understand the foundation, operation, organization and changes of Chinese local societies and their interaction with the State and global communities from a cross-disciplinary perspective.
(3) Students are expected to construct their own analysis framework which, hopefully, could be applied into their daily activities.

(1）作為比較及公眾史學文學碩士課程的一部分，本課程提供學生一個明白近代中國和海外華僑華人的新的理解。
(2）學生可以從跨學科的視角，理解中國地方社會與國家及環球世界的互動關係的基礎、運作、組織和變遷。
（3）學生修畢本科，可以建立其自身的分析能力和框架，從而應用到日常生活之中。
